{{Infobox football league season | competition = [[Czechoslovak First League]] | season = 1947–48 | winners = [[AC Sparta Prague|Sparta Prague]] | relegated = [[SK České Budějovice]]
[[Čechie Karlín]] | league topscorer = [[Jaroslav Cejp]]
(21 goals) | biggest home win = | biggest away win = | highest scoring = | matches = | total goals = | longest wins = | longest unbeaten = | longest losses = | highest attendance = | lowest attendance = | average attendance = | prevseason = [[1946–47 Czechoslovak First League|1946–47]] | nextseason = [[1948 Czechoslovak First League|1948]] }} Statistics of [[Czechoslovak First League]] in the 1947/1948 season. ==Overview== It was contested by 11 teams, and [[Sparta Prague]] won the championship. [[Jaroslav Cejp]] was the league's top scorer with 21 goals.{{cite book|first=Luboš|last=Jeřábek|title=Český a československý fotbal - lexikon osobností a klubů|publisher=Grada Publishing|language=Czech|year=2007|location=Prague, Czech Republic|isbn=978-80-247-1656-5|page=231}} ==League standings== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" |Pos||Club||P||W||D||L||F||A||Pts |- ||1||[[Sparta Prague]]||20||12||3||5||62||35||27 |- ||2||[[Slavia Prague]]||20||11||5||4||64||39||27 |- ||3||[[ŠK Slovan Bratislava|SK Bratislava]]||20||10||4||6||57||31||24 |- ||4||[[Bohemians 1905|FC Bohemians Praha]]||20||10||4||6||56||46||24 |- ||5||[[TSS Trnava]]||20||9||3||8||38||40||21 |- ||6||[[MFK Košice|Jednota Košice]]||20||7||6||7||46||39||20 |- ||7||[[FC Baník Ostrava|SK Slezská Ostrava]]||20||7||5||8||48||56||19 |- ||8||[[FC Viktoria Plzeň]]||20||8||1||11||48||56||17 |- ||9||[[MŠK Žilina]]||20||6||4||10||36||56||16 |- ||10||[[SK České Budějovice]]||20||4||5||11||42||80||13 |- ||11||[[Čechie Karlín]]||20||5||2||13||43||62||12 |} ==References== {{Reflist}} *[http://www.rsssf.com/tablest/tsjslhist.html Czechoslovakia - List of final tables (RSSSF)] {{Czechoslovak First League seasons}} {{1947–48 in European Football (UEFA)}} {{DEFAULTSORT:1947-48 Czechoslovak First League}} [[Category:Czechoslovak First League seasons]] [[Category:1947–48 in European association football leagues|Czechoslovak First League, 1947-48]] [[Category:1947–48 in Czechoslovak football]] {{Czechoslovakia-footy-competition-stub}}

{{Infobox International Handball Competition | tourney_name = Macedonian Handball Cup | year = 2011 | yearr = | other_titles = 2011 Cup of Macedonian Handball | image = | size = | caption = | country = | dates = 14 – 15 May | num_teams = 4 | confederations = | venues = [[Sports Hall Mladost]] | cities = [[Bitola]] | champion_other = [[RK Metalurg Skopje|RK Metalurg]] | count = 4 | second_other = [[RK Pelister]] | matches = 3 | goals = 146 | attendance = | top_scorer = | player = | updated = | previous = 2010 Macedonian Handball Cup | next = 2012 Macedonian Handball Cup }} The '''2011 Macedonian Handball Cup''' was the 19th edition of the [[Macedonian Handball Cup]]. It took place at the [[Sports Hall Mladost]] in [[Bitola]], [[Republic of Macedonia]], on 14 and 15 May 2011.[http://www.as-sport.com.mk/2011-05-04-23-19-54/rakomet/item/804-%D1%81%D0%B5%D0%BA%D0%BE%D1%98-%D1%81%D0%BE-%D1%81%D0%B2%D0%BE%D1%98%D0%B0-%D0%BF%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%81%D0%BC%D0%B5%D1%82%D0%BA%D0%B0-%D0%B7%D0%B0-%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BC%D0%B5%D1%82%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BE%D1%82-%D0%BA%D1%83%D0%BF-%D0%B2%D0%BE-%D0%B1%D0%B8%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B0.html Секој со своја пресметка за ракометниот куп во Битола]{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The cup was won by [[RK Metalurg Skopje|RK Metalurg]] for the fourth time.{{Cite web |url=http://kurir.mk/sport/rakomet/29624-Rakometniot-kup-na-Makedonija-za-Metalurg |title=Ракометниот куп на Македонија за Металург |access-date=2012-05-23 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111201011929/http://kurir.mk/sport/rakomet/29624-Rakometniot-kup-na-Makedonija-za-Metalurg |archive-date=2011-12-01 |dead-url=yes |df= }} == Venue ==
{| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ! [[Bitola]] |- | [[Sports Hall Mladost]] |- | Capacity: '''5,000''' |- |[[File:Map of Bitola Municipality.svg|150px]] |- |}

revision.text:
{| class="infobox vevent" style="width:20em; font-size:90%;" cellspacing="2" |- !colspan="2" style="font-size:larger; text-align:center" class="summary" |41st Chess Olympiad |- | style="text-align:center;" colspan="2"| [[File:Chess Olympiad 2014 official logo.png|300px]]
Logo of the 41st Chess Olympiad |- !Dates run |1–14 August 2014 |- !Competitors |1,570 (881 in open and 689 in women's event) |- !Teams |177 (Open)
136 (Women) |- !Nations |172 (Open)
131 (Women) |- !Venue |Mackhallen |- !Location |[[Tromsø]], [[Norway]] |- !colspan="2" class="navbox-abovebelow" | Champions |- !colspan="2" class="navbox-abovebelow" | Team |- !Open |{{gold1}} {{CHN}}
{{silver2}} {{HUN}}
{{bronze3}} {{IND}} |- !Women |{{gold1}} {{RUS}}
{{silver2}} {{CHN}}
{{bronze3}} {{UKR}} |- !colspan="2" class="navbox-abovebelow" | Individual |- !Open | {{flagicon|CHN}} [[Yu Yangyi]] |- !Women |{{flagicon|GEO}} [[Nana Dzagnidze]] |} The '''41st Chess Olympiad''', organised by the [[FIDE|Fédération Internationale des Échecs]] (FIDE) and comprising an openAlthough commonly referred to as the ''men's division'', this section is open to all male and female players. and women's tournament, as well as several events designed to promote the game of [[chess]], took place in [[Tromsø]], [[Norway]], between 1–14 August 2014.{{cite web|url=http://www.chessbase.com/newsdetail.asp?newsid=6718 |title=41st Chess Olympiad to be staged in – Tromsø! | Chess News |publisher=ChessBase|date= |accessdate=2014-01-24}} The organiser was Chess Olympiad Tromsø 2014 AS on behalf of FIDE. A total number of 1,570 players participated at the Olympiad, with 881 in the men and 689 in the women's section.[http://www.chessdom.com/tromso-chess-olympiad-men-live/ Tromso Chess Olympiad Men LIVE!], Chessdom.com, 29 July 2014.[http://www.chessdom.com/tromso-chess-olympiad-women-live/ Tromso Chess Olympiad Women LIVE!], Chessdom.com, 29 July 2014. The number of participating teams was 177 from 172 countries in the open section and 136 from 131 countries in the women's section. The main competitive events were held at Mackhallen. The Chief Arbiter of the event was [[Greece]]'s [[International Arbiter]] Panagiotis Nikolopoulos.[http://www.fide.com/component/content/article/1-fide-news/8008-tromso-chess-olympiad-officials-and-match-arbiters.html Tromso Chess Olympiad: Officials and Match Arbiters], [[FIDE]], 23 May 2014. The reigning World Champion, Norwegian Grandmaster [[Magnus Carlsen]], was one of the eight official ambassadors. He also played as a member of one of the Norwegian teams.{{cite web|url=https://chess24.com/en/olympiad2014/official-info/ambassadors/magnus-carlsen |title=Tromsø 2014: Ambassadors |publisher=official website |date= |accessdate=2014-05-26}}{{cite web|url=https://chess24.com/en/olympiad2014/news/magnus-carlsen-heads-norwegian-olympiad-teams |title=Magnus Carlsen heads Norwegian Olympiad teams |publisher=chess24.com |date= |accessdate=2014-05-26}} [[China]] won the open section of the tournament for the first time, while [[Russia]] claimed victory in the women's section for the third consecutive time as well as third time overall. Chinese [[Yu Yangyi]], playing on board three, and Georgian [[Nana Dzagnidze]], playing on board one, were the most successful players in the open and women's section, respectively.[http://en.chessbase.com/post/tromso-final Tromso Final], ChessBase, 14 August 2014. The event was also the last competitive tournament for [[Judit Polgár]], the strongest female chess player in history,Sources citing Polgár as by far the strongest female chess player of all time: *{{cite news | newspaper=Milwaukee Journal Sentinel | page=6A | title=Anand wins chess "Battle of the Sexes" | agency=Associated Press | date=2003-08-18 }} note: The Associated Press story on Aug.17/18, 2003 on the Polgár–Anand match explicitly refers to Polgár with the words "by far the strongest woman chess player ever" *{{cite web |url=http://m.eb.com/topic/467279/Judit-Polgar |title=Polgar, Judit |publisher=Encyclodedia Britannica Online |accessdate=May 8, 2011 }} note: explicitly uses "by far": "By far the strongest female player of all timer". *{{cite web |title=Super-GM tournament in Sofia starts |date=12 May 2005 |publisher=Chessbase.com |url=http://www.chessbase.com/newsdetail.asp?newsid=2375 |accessdate=18 April 2010 }} *{{cite web |title=Judit Polgár: 'I can work myself into the top ten again' |publisher=[[ChessBase]] |url=http://www.chessbase.com/newsdetail.asp?newsid=4244 |date=2007-11-11 |accessdate=2008-02-04 }} *{{cite news |title=Chess; The Secret of Playing Blindfold: Memory May Be the Least of It |last=McClain |first=Dylan Loeb |date=2006-12-24 |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9E00EED71131F937A15751C1A9609C8B63 |accessdate=13 April 2010 |work=The New York Times }} *{{cite web |url=http://michaelbluejay.com/misc/womengrandmasters.html |title=Women Grandmasters in Chess |accessdate=2010-04-13 |publisher=MichaelBluejay }} *{{cite news |last=Pein |first=Malcolm |title=A crown for Kosteniuk |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |date=2009-09-22 |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/chess/malcolmpein/3561123/A-crown-for-Kosteniuk.html |accessdate=2010-04-18 |location=London }} Malcolm Pein, British IM and Executive Editor of [[CHESS magazine]], when speaking of A. Kosteniuk's victory over Hou Yifan for the Women's World Champtionship, said "Currently Judit Polgár is in another league from any other female player." *{{cite news |title=Elite Players Of Chess To Compete |date=2005-05-17 |newspaper=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/05/17/arts/17chess.html |accessdate=2010-04-18 }} *{{cite book | title=Human cloning | last1=Humber | first1=James M. | last2=Almeder | first2=Robert F. | page=87 | publisher=Humana Press inc. | isbn=0-89603-565-4 }} *{{cite news | newspaper=Milwaukee Journal Sentinel | date=1996-12-22 | page=17A | last=Weber | first=Bruce | title=Next Move? Chess enthusiasts puzzle over game's gender imbalance }} *{{cite book | last=Wolff | first=Patrick | title=Complete Idiot's guide to chess | publisher=Penguin Group (USA) Inc. | year=2002 | page=277 | authorlink=Patrick Wolff | isbn=0-02-864182-5 }} *{{cite news | newspaper=The Washington Post | last=Kavalek | first=Lubomir | title=Chess | date=2005-01-17 | page=C12 | authorlink=Lubomir Kavalek }} Kavalek, GM in the top 100 players for 26 years, called Polgár, "the all-time best female player" *{{cite book | title=Treasure Chess: Trivia, Quotes, Puzzles, and Lore from the World's Oldest Game | last=Pandolfini | first=Bruce | authorlink=Bruce Pandolfini | page=84 | publisher=Random House | year=2007 | isbn=978-0-375-72204-2 }} Panolfini, chess author and coach, writes "Judit Polgár is simply the strongest female chess player in history." *The January 1996 FIDE ratings list was a landmark as Polgár's 2675 rating made her the No. 10 ranked player in the world, the only woman ever to enter the world's Top Ten. {{cite news | newspaper=The Globe and Mail | location=Toronto | last=Berry | title=Kramnick, 20 Tops the rating list | first=Jonathan | page=A12 | date=1996-01-06 }} *{{cite web |title=All Time Rankings:FIDE Top 10 1970–1997 |publisher=The University of Edinburgh |url=http://chess.eusa.ed.ac.uk/Chess/Trivia/AlltimeList.html |accessdate=2010-05-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091126000035/http://chess.eusa.ed.ac.uk/Chess/Trivia/AlltimeList.html |archivedate=2009-11-26 |df= }} who announced her retirement from competitive chess in the rest day of the Olympiad.[http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/puzzles/chess/article4174361.ece Queen who exposed the arrogance of kings], ''[[The Times]]'', 13 August 2014.[http://www.theweekinchess.com/chessnews/events/41st-olympiad-tromso-2014/judit-polgar-to-retire-from-professional-chess Judit Polgar to retire from professional chess], ''[[The Week in Chess]]'', 13 August 2014.[http://en.chessbase.com/post/judit-polgar-to-retire-from-competitive-chess Judit Polgar to retire from competitive chess], ChessBase, 13 August 2014. Playing as a reserve player for [[Hungary]] in the open section, she won a silver medal with her team and recorded four wins, one loss and one draw for a total score 4½/6. == Preparations == [[File:41st Chess Olympiad participants.png|thumb|300px|{{Legend-table |title=Participating nations |#00ff00|Participating in both open and women's tournament |green|Participating only in open tournament }}]] There were two cities bidding to host the event: [[Albena]] and [[Tromsø]]. The bidding procedure, which was held in 2010 in [[Khanty-Mansiysk]], lasted several days; in the end the Norwegians won by a 95–47 vote. In May 2014, it was announced that the budget for the Olympiad would cost 15 million [[Norwegian krone|NOK]]. However, the Norwegians initially did not know that they also had to organise the [[Chess World Cup 2013]] and therefore they did not take into account the cost for this event in the amount of €2 million. The organisers requested additional funding for the Olympiad apart from the 75 million NOK that were already secured, but the Norwegian government did not approve it. Then, they sought sponsorships to cover the unanticipated expenses, and managed to attract private sponsors.Peter Doggers: [http://www.chess.com/news/troms-olympiad-in-trouble-3259 Tromsø Olympiad in Trouble?], [[Chess.com]], 14 May 2014. In June 2014, the Norwegian parliament approved an additional 12 million NOK for staging the event, whereupon the organisers confirmed that the Chess Olympiad would take place in Tromsø.Peter Doggers: [http://schach.chess.com/news/troms-olympiad-saved-receives-extra-state-funding-8648 Tromsø Olympiad Saved, Receives Extra State Funding], Chess.com, 5 June 2014. The Administrative Director of Chess Olympiad Tromsø 2014 AS was Børge Robertsen. Chairman of the board was [[Henrik Andenæs]], but later he was replaced by [[Herman Kristoffersen]].{{cite news|author=Henriksen, Thor Harald|title=Han fikk ikke vinter-OL til Tromsø. Men Herman ble ikke sjakk matt|pages=8–9|work=VG Sportbilag|date=19 October 2010|language=Norwegian}} There were eight ambassadors of the Olympiad: the reigning World Champion [[Magnus Carlsen]];{{cite web|url=https://chess24.com/en/olympiad2014/official-info/ambassadors/magnus-carlsen |title=Tromsø 2014: Ambassadors - Magnus Carlsen |publisher=official website |date= |accessdate= }} former World Champion [[Anatoly Karpov]];{{cite web|url=https://chess24.com/en/olympiad2014/official-info/ambassadors/anatoly-karpov |title=Tromsø 2014: Ambassadors - Anatoly Karpov |publisher=official website |date= |accessdate= }} former Women's World Champions [[Susan Polgar]] and [[Alexandra Kosteniuk]];{{cite web|url=https://chess24.com/en/olympiad2014/official-info/ambassadors/susan-polgar |title=Tromsø 2014: Ambassadors - Susan Polgar |publisher=official website |date= |accessdate= }}{{cite web|url=https://chess24.com/en/olympiad2014/official-info/ambassadors/alexandra-kosteniuk |title=Tromsø 2014: Ambassadors - Alexandra Kosteniuk |publisher=official website |date= |accessdate= }} Woman Grandmaster [[Melanie Ohme]];{{cite web|url=https://chess24.com/en/olympiad2014/official-info/ambassadors/melanie-ohme |title=Tromsø 2014: Ambassadors - Melanie Ohme |publisher=official website |date= |accessdate= }} the historian, crime author, chess player and organiser, and politician [[Hans Olav Lahlum]];{{cite web|url=https://chess24.com/en/olympiad2014/official-info/ambassadors/hans-olav-lahlum |title=Tromsø 2014: Ambassadors - Hans Olav Lahlum |publisher=official website |date= |accessdate= }} former footballer [[Sigurd Rushfeldt]];{{cite web|url=https://chess24.com/en/olympiad2014/official-info/ambassadors/sigurd-rushfeldt |title=Tromsø 2014: Ambassadors - Sigurd Rushfeldt |publisher=official website |date= |accessdate= }} and the adventurer and journalist [[Lars Monsen]].{{cite web|url=https://chess24.com/en/olympiad2014/official-info/ambassadors/lars-monsen |title=Tromsø 2014: Ambassadors - Lars Monsen |publisher=official website |date= |accessdate= }} The playing venue was Mackhallen, which is situated in downtown Tromsø. Mackhallen is the former site of the world's most northerly brewery, [[Macks Ølbryggeri|Mack Brewery]], dating back to 1877.{{cite web|url=https://chess24.com/en/olympiad2014/tromso/the-venue |title=Tromsø 2014: The Venue |publisher=official website |date= |accessdate=2014-05-26}} == The event == === Competition format and calendar === The tournament was played in a [[Swiss-system tournament|Swiss system format]]. The [[time control]] for every single game was 90 minutes per 40 moves, with addition of 30 seconds per move and 30 minutes after the 40th move. It is allowed once again for a player to offer a [[Draw by agreement|draw]] at any time during the game. A total of 11 rounds were played, in which every team played with four of their players against another team. Every team was allowed to nominate one reserve player.{{cite web|url=http://www.fide.com/fide/handbook.html?id=95&view=article |title=FIDE Handbook: Olympiad Pairing Rules |publisher=Fide.com |date= |accessdate=2014-08-21}} Teams were ranked according to the match points won in every round. In case of same number of match points by two or more teams, the tie-breaker was decided by applying: 1. The [[Sonneborn-Berger]] system; 2. Total game points scored; 3. Sum of the match points of the opponents, excluding the lowest one. The opening ceremony of the Chess Olympiad was held at 19:30 [[Central European Summer Time|CEST]] ([[UTC+02:00|UTC+2]]) on 1 August and the closing ceremony was held at 20:00 CEST (UTC+2) on 14 August. Tournament rounds started on 2 August and ended with the final round on 14 August. All rounds started at 14:00 CEST (UTC+2), except for the first and the final round which started at 15:00 CEST (UTC+2) and 11:00 CEST (UTC+2), respectively. There were two rest days at the tournament, the first one on 7 August after the fifth round and the second one on 13 August before the final round. In addition, the Arbiters meeting took place at 21:30 CEST (UTC+2) on 1 August and the Captains meeting at 09:00 CEST (UTC+2) on 2 August.{{cite web|url=https://chess24.com/en/olympiad2014/official-info/schedule |title=Tromsø 2014: Schedule |publisher=official website |date= |accessdate= }} :''All dates are [[Central European Summer Time|CEST]] ([[UTC+02:00|UTC+2]])''

=== Open event === [[File:Yu Yangyi.jpg|thumb|upright|Yu Yangyi of China won the individual gold medal in the open event.]] The open section of the tournament was contested by a record number of 177 teams representing 172 nations. Norway, as host nation, fielded three teams, whilst the [[International Braille Chess Association]] (IBCA), the International Physically Disabled Chess Association (IPCA), and the International Chess Committee of the Deaf (ICCD) each provided one team. Players who participated at the Olympiad included the reigning World Champion and highest rated player in the world Magnus Carlsen, nine of the top ten players from the FIDE rating list published in July 2014, and four former World Champions. The former World Champion [[Vishwanathan Anand]], who was the challenger in the [[World Chess Championship 2014]], was the only player from the top ten who missed the Olympiad. The highest rated female chess player, [[Judit Polgár]], represented Hungary in the open section. However, not all of the teams submitted their strongest line-ups for the Olympiad. [[China]], who were expected to be one of the strongest teams in the tournament, were represented by only two players rated above 2700. [[Russia]] were the strongest team in the open section with an average rating of 2777 points, followed by [[Ukraine]] with 2722 and [[France]], led by [[Maxime Vachier-Lagrave]], with 2718. Other teams with average ratings higher than 2700 rating points were [[Armenia]], with the World no. 2 [[Levon Aronian]], playing on the top board, the [[United States of America]], and [[Hungary]].[http://en.chessbase.com/post/tromso-2014-preview-and-preparations Tromso 2014: Preview and preparations], ChessBase, 27 July 2014. China won their first gold in the open event and remained the only unbeaten team in the tournament. They scored eight wins and three draws for a total of 19 points, finishing two points clear of the opposition. Second place was shared by four teams on 17 points: [[Hungary]], [[India]], Russia and [[Azerbaijan]]. Hungary won the tie-breaker for second place to claim the silver medal, and India ranked third to win the bronze medal. Russia, who were once again clear favourites before the tournament, finished in fourth place. Armenia, the defending champions from the previous Chess Olympiad, scored 16 points to finish in eighth place.[https://chess24.com/en/olympiad2014/news/final-interim-report-looking-the-part China and Russia claim gold!], official website, 14 August 2014. :{| class="wikitable" |+ Open event ! # !! Yu Yangyi on the third board had the best performance of all players in the tournament: * Board 1: {{flagicon|BUL}} [[Veselin Topalov]] 2872 * Board 2: {{flagicon|VIE}} [[Nguyễn Ngọc Trường Sơn]] 2843 * '''Board 3: {{flagicon|CHN}} [[Yu Yangyi]] 2912''' * Board 4: {{flagicon|SRB}} [[Nikola Sedlak]] 2773 * Reserve: {{flagicon|USA}} [[Sam Shankland]] 2831 === Women's event === [[File:Dzagnidze nana 20081119 olympiade dresden.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Nana Dzagnidze]] of Georgia won the individual gold medal in the women's event.]] The women's event was contested by 136 teams representing 131 nations. Norway, as host nation, fielded three teams, whilst the [[International Braille Chess Association]] (IBCA), the International Physically Disabled Chess Association (IPCA), and the International Chess Committee of the Deaf (ICCD) each provided one team. Among the players who played in the women's section were the reigning Women's World Champion [[Hou Yifan]], seven of the top ten players from the FIDE rating list published in July 2014 (excluding Polgar who plays in the open section), and three former Women's World Champions. [[Koneru Humpy]] of India and [[Viktorija Čmilytė]] of Lithuania were the only two from the top ten female chess players to miss the Olympiad. China were the strongest team in the women's section, having brought all their strongest players, with an average rating of 2544. Russia were the second highest rated team with an average rating of 2521, and was represented by [[Kateryna Lagno]] on board one, [[Alexandra Kosteniuk]], [[Natalia Pogonina]], and [[Valentina Gunina]]. Ukraine with an average of 2505 rating points were the third highest rated team, having [[Anna Muzychuk|Anna]] and [[Mariya Muzychuk]] as well as the former Women's World Champion [[Anna Ushenina]] in their line-up. Russia claimed victory in the women's event for the third consecutive time, scoring ten wins and one loss for a total of 20 points. China and Ukraine tied for second place with 18 points, but the Chinese won the tie-breaker to claim silver, and Ukraine finished third to take the bronze. Russia and China both had perfect scores before their match in the seventh round, when the Russians defeated their opponents 3-1, making a decisive margin for capturing the gold. :{| class="wikitable" |+ Women's event ! # !! Nana Dzagnidze on the first board had the best performance of all players in the tournament: * '''Board 1: {{flagicon|GEO}} [[Nana Dzagnidze]] 2719''' * Board 2: {{flagicon|RUS}} [[Valentina Gunina]] 2651 * Board 3: {{flagicon|RUS}} [[Alexandra Kosteniuk]] 2639 * Board 4: {{flagicon|UKR}} [[Natalia Zhukova]] 2512 * Reserve: {{flagicon|IND}} [[Padmini Rout]] 2584 === Gaprindashvili Trophy === The [[Nona Gaprindashvili]] Trophy is awarded to the nation that has the highest total number of match points in the open and women's divisions combined. Where two or more teams are tied, they are ordered by the same tie breakers as in the two separate events. The trophy, named after the former women's World Champion (1961–78), was created by FIDE in 1997. {| class="wikitable" style="font-size: 95%;" |- ! # ! Team ! MP ! dSB |- | style="background:gold;"| '''1''' | '''{{CHN}}''' | '''37''' | '''828.5''' |- | style="background:silver;"| 2 | {{RUS}} | 37 | 772.5 |- | style="background:#c96;"| 3 | {{UKR}} | 34 | |} == FIDE presidential election == The FIDE presidential election was held at the 85th FIDE Congress, which took place during the Olympiad. All of the 177 member nations of FIDE were eligible to vote for one of the two candidates: the incumbent FIDE President [[Kirsan Ilyumzhinov]] and the former World Chess Champion [[Garry Kasparov]]. Prior to the Congress, Kasparov reproached FIDE for irregularities in the published list of delegates and at least one member of the FIDE Electoral Commission (ELE) agreed with him.[http://www.chess.com/news/delegate-issues-deepen-for-fide-elections-6742 Delegate Issues Deepen for FIDE Elections], Chess.com, 18 July 2014. Finally, Ilyumzhinov defeated Kasparov by 49 votes (110 votes for the incumbent president and 61 for Kasparov).[http://en.chessbase.com/post/kirsan-ilyumzhinov-remains-fide-president Kirsan Ilyumzhinov remains FIDE President], ChessBase, 11 August 2014. == Controversies == On 7 July 2014, FIDE President Kirsan Ilyumzhinov complained in an open letter to the Prime Minister of Norway [[Erna Solberg]] that some teams had difficulties in obtaining travel visas. In the letter he mentioned that the team members with no Norwegian embassies or consulates in their countries had to travel to another country in order to apply for visas; moreover, each team member had to do it individually and in person.[http://www.fide.com/component/content/article/1-fide-news/8134-presidents-letter-to-the-prime-minister-of-norway-.html President's letter to the Prime Minister of Norway], [[FIDE]], 7 July 2014. A day later, Børge Robertsen, administrative director of the Olympiad, responded on behalf of the organisers and notified them that they were working hard on the matter, and had already sent approximately 1,500 invitation letters to participants who required visas. He also stated that the entire visa application process is easy to follow and can be handled online.[http://en.chessbase.com/post/visa-problems-for-the-chess-olympiad Visa problems for the Chess Olympiad], [[ChessBase]], 10 July 2014. [[File:Fondation Neva Women's Grand Prix Geneva 11-05-2013 - Kateryna Lagno.jpg|upright|thumb|left|[[Kateryna Lagno]]'s transfer from Ukraine to Russia caused controversy prior to the Olympiad.]] On 16 July 2014, the organising committee announced that some national teams had missed the 1 June deadline to submit their team line-ups. They included [[Central African Republic]], [[Gabon]], [[Ivory Coast]], [[Cambodia]], [[Oman]], [[Pakistan]] and [[Senegal]] in the open, as well as [[Afghanistan]] and [[Russia]] in the women's section.[https://chess24.com/en/olympiad2014/news/late-entries-excluded-from-chess-olympiad Late entries excluded from Chess Olympiad], Chess24.com, 16 July 2014.[https://chess24.com/en/read/news/russian-reigning-champions-miss-2014-olympiad Russian reigning champions may miss 2014 Olympiad], Chess24.com, 17 July 2014 The organisers also stated that the regulations regarding the deadline applied to all, and that no exceptions would be allowed. Particularly surprising was the disqualification of Russia's women's team, as they were reigning champions from the previous Chess Olympiad. The chess media linked the missed deadline with Kateryna Lagno's circumstance of changing federations, and reported that the Russian Chess Federation allowed the deadline to pass, while awaiting her transfer from Ukraine to Russia to become official. It was alleged that [[Kateryna Lagno]] was needed to strengthen Russia's women's team following the retirement of [[Nadezhda Kosintseva|Nadezhda]] and [[Tatiana Kosintseva]]. FIDE criticised the decision of the organisers not to allow these teams to compete at the Olympiad. FIDE Vice President Israel Gelfer said that the ultimate decision of allowing teams to compete lays in the hands of Kirsan Ilyumzhinov. In addition, he implicated Garry Kasparov, and advocated cancelling the Olympiad. Gelfer said that the organising committee was influenced by people who are working for Kasparov, and that they were using it for election purposes.[http://en.chessbase.com/post/russian-women-s-team-out-of-olympiad Russian Women's team out of Olympiad], ChessBase, 17 July 2014. Kasparov responded promptly, and characterized Gelfer's statements as 'bizarre', stating that to punish 175 teams for the mistakes of one was an absurd arrogance. He also criticised FIDE for allowing the Russian Chess Federation to violate the rules and receive an exception, and said that it was a real threat to the global chess community.[http://en.chessbase.com/post/garry-kasparov-on-the-threat-to-troms Garry Kasparov on the threat to Tromsø], ChessBase, 17 July 2014. On 21 July, the organising committee informed FIDE President Ilyumzhinov that, while they stood by the interpretation of the regulations, they would allow the teams who had missed the 1 June deadline to play.{{cite web|url=http://en.chessbase.com/post/organisers-stand-by-case-but-allow-teams-to-play |title=Organisers stand by case but allow teams to play|publisher=En.chessbase.com |date=21 July 2014 |accessdate=2014-08-21}} == Deaths == The final day of competition was marred by the deaths of the Swiss-born Seychelles player Kurt Meier, who suffered a heart attack during his game, and Alisher Anarkulov, an [[Uzbekistan|Uzbek]] representing the International Chess Committee of the Deaf, who was found dead in his hotel room shortly afterwards. The closing ceremony began with a [[minute of silence]] to mark the two deaths.{{cite web | url =http://chess-news.ru/en/node/16440| title =Two Deaths at Olympiad: Another Participant Passes Away |publisher =Chess-News|date=15 Aug 2014| accessdate = 15 Aug 2014}} == References == {{reflist|27em}} == External links == {{Portal|Chess}} {{Commons category|Chess Olympiad 2014|41st Chess Olympiad}} * {{Official website|https://chess24.com/en/olympiad2014}} * Results: ** [http://chess-results.com/tnr140380.aspx?lan=1&art=1&flag=30&wi=821 Open event] ** [http://chess-results.com/tnr140381.aspx?lan=1&art=1&flag=30&wi=821 Women's event] {{Chess Olympiads}} [[Category:2014 in chess]] [[Category:2014 in Norwegian sport]] [[Category:Chess in Norway]] [[Category:Chess Olympiads]] [[Category:International sports competitions hosted by Norway]] [[Category:Sport in Tromsø]] [[Category:Women's Chess Olympiads]]

{{Infobox beverage |name = All Sport |image = |introduced = 1993 |manufacturer = All Sport, Inc. (distributed by [[Keurig Dr Pepper]]) |type= Nutrient Enhanced Sports Drink Beverage |origin=United States |website = [http://www.drinkallsport.com/ drinkallsport.com] }}
'''All Sport''' is a brand of [[sports drink]], whose competitors include [[Gatorade]] and [[Powerade]]. It was created by [[PepsiCo]], as their response to [[The Coca-Cola Company]]'s Powerade and [[Quaker Oats Company|Quaker Oat's]] Gatorade. After PepsiCo's acquisition of Quaker Oats Company, in 2001, All Sport was sold to [[Monarch Beverage Company|The Monarch Beverage Company]], of [[Atlanta]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]]. In 2007, All Sport was purchased by privately held [[Big Red (drink)|Big Red, Inc.]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bigredltd.com/history |title=History |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060523191042/http://www.bigredltd.com/history |archivedate=23 May 2006 |deadurl=yes |accessdate=24 August 2016 |df= }}</ref> It is distributed by [[Keurig Dr Pepper]].
All Sport originally was lightly carbonated, but this was changed after consumers objected. It was also originally marketed as a "Thirst Quencher" like Gatorade but was soon changed to market it as a "Body Quencher" and, more recently, a "Non Carbonated Sports Drink".
==Products==
===All Sport Body Quencher===
*Fruit Punch *Blue Raz Ice *Grape *Orange *Lemon Lime *Black citrus
====Ingredients==== Ingredients include water, [[high fructose corn syrup]], [[citric acid]], [[phosphoric acid]], [[monopotassium phosphate]], [[sodium chloride]], [[gum arabic]], [[ascorbic acid]] (vitamin C), natural and artificial flavors, [[calcium chloride]], and [[ester gum]].
===All Sport Zero=== *Blue Raz *Orange *Fruit Punch flavors
==Discontinued products==
===All Sport Naturally Zero=== All Sport Naturally Zero was a zero calorie sports drink, sweetened with [[Truvia]]. When it was released in April 2009, Naturally Zero was the first and only zero calorie sports drink sweetened with Truvia.<ref> {{cite web|url=http://news.drpeppersnapplegroup.com/press-release/product-news/all-sport-and-dr-pepper-snapple-group-introduce-first-sports-drink-natura |title=All Sport and Dr Pepper Snapple Group Introduce the First Sports Drink Naturally Sweetened With Stevia |accessdate=4 August 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140808053157/http://news.drpeppersnapplegroup.com/press-release/product-news/all-sport-and-dr-pepper-snapple-group-introduce-first-sports-drink-natura |archivedate=8 August 2014 }}</ref>
*Strawberry Star Fruit *Dragonfruit *Mandarin Orange
====Ingredients==== Ingredients include water, citric acid, fruit and vegetable extracts (for natural color), natural flavor, [[potassium citrate]], salt, [[Rebaudioside A|rebiana]], calcium chloride, and [[B vitamins]] ([[niacinamide]] (B<sub>3</sub>), [[calcium pantothenate]] (B<sub>5</sub>), [[pyridoxine hydrochloride]] (B<sub>6</sub>), and [[cyanocobalamin]] (B<sub>12</sub>)).
==Sponsorships== [[File:All Sport trailer.jpg|290px|right|Jeremy Mayfield's 2009 Sprint Cup hauler, with All Sport decals.]] All Sport has sponsored several athletes and teams.
*Most notably with [[Tommy Kendall]] in the [[Trans-Am Series]] through the nineties. *[[Alexi Lalas]], Soccer *[[John Daly (golfer)|John Daly]], PGA Professional Golfer<ref>http://news.prnewswire.com/ViewContent.aspx?ACCT=109&STORY=/www/story/06-04-2009/0005038405&EDATE= {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090616031516/http://news.prnewswire.com/ViewContent.aspx?ACCT=109&STORY=%2Fwww%2Fstory%2F06-04-2009%2F0005038405&EDATE= |date=2009-06-16 }}</ref> *[[Germain Racing]] with [[Mike Skinner (racing driver)|Mike Skinner]], [[NASCAR]] *[[Travis Kvapil]], of the Yates Racing Team *[[Enrique Bernoldi]], Indy 500 & Sonoma *[[Erick Dampier]], Dallas Basketball Center *BMX Stunt Team 720 *Jeremy Mayfield *Cleveland Indians *Pepsi All Sports 8-9 year old AAU basketball team in Maine. A few wins away from nationals. *Cole Everson

{{Infobox Organization |name = Arab Chess Federation
الاتحاد العربي للشطرنج |image = Arab_Chess_Federation.PNG |size = 200 px |motto = ''Arab as one Nation'' |type = |formation = July 27, 1975 |headquarters = [[United Arab Emirates]], [[Dubai]] |membership = 18 member states |leader_title = President |leader_name = [[Ibrahim Mohammed Al Bannai]] |language = |website= [http://www.arabfide.com/ www.arabfide.com] }} The '''Arab Chess Federation''' ('''ArabFide''') ({{lang-ar|الاتحاد العربي للشطرنج}}) is a non-profit organization that promotes [[chess]] within the [[Arab world]]. Though unaffiliated with the [[Arab League]], it includes 18 of the latter's member states. ==History== Formed on July 27, 1975 in [[Damascus]], [[Syria]], the federation was established under the motto "Arab as one Nation". Mr. [[Nahed El Khany]] was the organization's first president. In 2015, the Arab Chess Federation co-organized the 1st edition of the Arab Chess Olympiad Championships in Agadir, Morocco.[http://www.chessdom.com/first-arab-chess-olympiad-championships-2015-to-be-held-in-agadir/ First Arab Chess Olympiad Championships 2015 to be held in Agadir], ''Chessdom.com'', 25 August 2015 ==Governance== *President: Ibrahim Mohammed El-Bannay *Official representatives: **{{JOR}} – Abd-Ul-Malik Arafat **{{TUN}} – Mohammed Ali El-Mehrezy **{{SYR}} – Hossam El-Din Menaqly **{{KWT}} – Rashid El-Rahmany **{{LBN}} – Mohammed Mourad Soukar **{{LBA}} – Mohammed Shokry Shahin **{{EGY}} – Ellowa Ismail Mekkey *Members: **{{ALG}} **{{BHR}} **{{EGY}} **{{IRQ}} **{{JOR}} **{{KWT}} **{{LBN}} **{{LBA}} **{{MTN}} **{{MAR}} **{{PSE}} **{{QAT}} **{{SOM}} **{{SUD}} **{{SYR}} **{{TUN}} **{{UAE}} **{{YEM}} ==Other chess federations== * [[Egyptian Chess Federation]] * [[Qatar Chess Federation]] * [[UAE Chess Federation]] ==Best 40 Arab players== {| class="wikitable" |- ! revision.text:
{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Blair Field | nickname = | image = Blair Field (Long Beach, California).jpg | fullname = | location = 4700 Deukmejian Drive
Long Beach, CA 90804 | coordinates = {{coord|33|46|40|N|118|8|18|W|type:landmark|display=it}} | broke_ground = | built = | opened = April 11, 1958 | renovated = 1992, 1999 | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = City of Long Beach | operator = City of Long Beach | surface = Grass | construction_cost = $500,000 | architect = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor= | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = | tenants =[[Long Beach State 49ers baseball|Long Beach State Dirtbags]] ([[Big West Conference|Big West]]) (1993-present)
[[Long Beach Armada]] ([[Golden Baseball League|GBL]]) (2005-2009)
[[Long Beach Breakers]] ([[Western Baseball League|WBL]]) (2001-2002)
Long Beach Riptide ([[Western Baseball League|WBL]]) (1995-1996)
[[Chicago Cubs]] ([[National League|NL]]) (1966) (spring training) | seating_capacity = 3,238 | dimensions = Left - 348 ft.
Center - 400 ft.
Right - 348 ft. }} '''Blair Field''' is a [[stadium]] in [[Long Beach, California]]. It originally opened in 1956 and is primarily used for [[baseball]]. It holds 3,238 people. It is named for Frank Blair, the sports editor for the ''[[Long Beach Press-Telegram]]'' newspaper for 32 years.{{cite news |first=Bob |last=Keisser |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Historic Blair Field never looked better |url=http://www.presstelegram.com/search/ci_8871094?IADID=Search-www.presstelegram.com-www.presstelegram.com |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110613203314/http://www.presstelegram.com/search/ci_8871094?IADID=Search-www.presstelegram.com-www.presstelegram.com |dead-url=yes |archive-date=June 13, 2011 |work=[[Long Beach Press-Telegram]] |publisher= |date=April 9, 2008 |accessdate=2008-05-26 }} Located in [[Recreation Park (Long Beach, California)|Recreation Park]], it was constructed in 1958 and over the years has fostered local amateur baseball and hosted [[Moore League]] high school [[American football|football]] and [[Amateur baseball in the United States|baseball]] teams, along with [[American Legion Baseball|American Legion]] and Connie Mack baseball. The [[Chicago Cubs]] baseball team held spring training at the ballpark in [[1966 Chicago Cubs season|1966]], the [[Los Angeles Rams]] football team and [[Olympic Games|Olympic]] teams have used the site for practice or [[exhibition game]]s. It is the home of the [[Long Beach State 49ers baseball]] team, "[[the Dirtbags]]," and former home of the defunct Western Baseball League team, the Long Beach Breakers, and the defunct [[Golden Baseball League]] team, the [[Long Beach Armada]]. In 1992, $1.475 million was spent to renovate the 3,238-seat facility. New spectator seating, field lights, a playing field with state-of-the-art drainage system, and turf which exceeds professional baseball standards were installed. Additional improvements, including 774 new box seats and a new scoreboard, were made in 1999.{{cite web |url=http://longbeachstate.cstv.com/facilities/blair.html |title=Blair Field |accessdate=2008-03-17 |author= |date= |work=www.longbeachstate.cstv.com |publisher=}} ==Attendance== In 2012, the Dirtbags ranked 46th among [[List of NCAA Division I baseball programs|Division I baseball programs]] in attendance, averaging 1,391 per home game.{{cite web |last=Foley |first=Brian |title=2012 NCAA Baseball Attendance Report |url=http://www.collegebaseballdaily.com/2012/06/13/2012-ncaa-baseball-attendance-report/ |work=CollegeBaseballDaily.com |accessdate=14 June 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/68QP2cfcO?url=http://www.collegebaseballdaily.com/2012/06/13/2012-ncaa-baseball-attendance-report/ |archivedate=2012-06-14 |date=13 June 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }} ==Other uses== Blair Field has hosted six [[MTV Rock N' Jock]] softball games. It has also been the filming location for numerous film, TV, and commercial productions, including the movies ''[[Space Jam]]''{{cite web |title=Filming Locations for Space Jam |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0117705/locations |work=The Internet Movie Database (IMDB) |accessdate=30 November 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/63aVhTOhc?url=http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0117705/locations |archivedate=2011-11-30 |deadurl=yes |df= }}{{cite web |last=Warner Brothers |title=Production Notes |url=http://www.cinemareview.com/static-htm/119607pn.htm |publisher=Five Star Publishing |accessdate=30 November 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/63aVnP9dh?url=http://www.cinemareview.com/static-htm/119607pn.htm |archivedate=2011-11-30 |year=1996 |quote=Off-stage locations for the live-action sequences included Blair Field in Long Beach, for scenes recreating Jordan's season with the Birmingham Barons baseball team... |deadurl=yes |df= }} and ''[[Moneyball (film)|Moneyball]]''.{{cite news |last=Ugland |first=Devin |title=Brad Pitt’s ‘Moneyball’ shot at Blair Field |url=http://www.daily49er.com/sports/2011/10/02/brad-pitts-moneyball-shot-at-blair-field/ |accessdate=October 4, 2011 |newspaper=Daily 49er |date=October 3, 2011}} The [[Minnesota Vikings]] practiced at Blair Field prior to [[Super Bowl XI]] in nearby [[Rose Bowl (stadium)|Pasadena]].{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Super Bowl Notebook |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=zRgVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=lF0DAAAAIBAJ&pg=5816,5119463&dq=blair-field+long+beach |newspaper=[[St. Petersburg Times]]|page=4C |publisher= |date=1977-01-07 |accessdate=2009-09-01}} ==Gallery== File:Blair Field (Long Beach, CA).jpg|Blair Field main entrance File:Blair Field Grandstand (Long Beach, California).jpg|Blair Field grandstand File:Blair Field Recreation Park Long Beach California.jpg|Blair Field - Recreation Park ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I baseball venues]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070503143000/http://www.longbeach.gov/park/facilities/sports.asp City of Long Beach Department of Parks and Recreation: Blair Field] *[http://www.longbeachstate.com/facilities/blair.html Long Beach State Athletics: Blair Field] *[http://www.digitalballparks.com/SpringTraining/Blair.html Digital Ballparks: Blair Field] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090428134440/http://www.ballparkreviews.com/lb/lb.htm Ballpark Reviews: Blair Field] {{California State University, Long Beach}} {{Big West Conference baseball venue navbox}} {{California NCAA Division I college baseball venue navbox}} {{Chicago Cubs}} [[Category:Chicago Cubs spring training venues]] [[Category:Minor league baseball venues]] [[Category:College baseball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Sports venues in Long Beach, California]] [[Category:Spring training ballparks]] [[Category:Long Beach State Dirtbags baseball]] [[Category:Baseball venues in California]] [[Category:1958 establishments in California]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1958]]

page.title: California League Most Valuable Player Award

revision.text:
{{Infobox award | name = California League
Most Valuable Player Award | current_awards = | image = | imagesize = | alt = | caption = | description = California League's Regular Season MVP | presenter = | host = | location = | country = [[United States]] | reward = | year = 1941 | year2 = | holder = [[Rylan Bannon]] | website = }} The '''California League Most Valuable Player Award''' ('''MVP''') is an annual award given to the best player in [[minor league baseball|minor league baseball's]] [[California League]]. In 1941, [[Spider Jorgensen|John Jorgensen]] won the first ever California League MVP Award. [[First basemen]], with 12 winners, have won the most among [[infielders]], followed by [[shortstop]]s (6), [[third basemen]] (5), and [[second basemen]] (4). Eight [[catcher]]s have also won the award. Seven players who won the award were [[pitcher]]s. Twenty-six [[outfielder]]s have won the MVP Award, the most of any position. Six players played during seasons for which position information is unavailable. Sixteen players from the [[Los Angeles Dodgers|Brooklyn/Los Angeles Dodgers]] [[Major League Baseball]] (MLB) organization have won the MVP Award, more than any other, followed by the [[San Diego Padres]] organization (7); the [[Los Angeles Angels|California/Los Angeles Angels]], [[Minnesota Twins]], and [[San Francisco Giants]] organizations (5); the [[St. Louis Cardinals]] organization (4); the [[Oakland Athletics|Kansas City/Oakland Athletics]] and [[Milwaukee Brewers]] organization (3); the [[Arizona Diamondbacks]], [[Baltimore Orioles]], [[Boston Red Sox]], [[Cincinnati Reds]], [[Pittsburgh Pirates]], [[Seattle Mariners]], and [[Tampa Bay Devil Rays]] organizations (2); and the [[Chicago Cubs]], [[Cleveland Indians]], [[Colorado Rockies]], [[Florida Marlins]], [[Houston Astros]], and [[New York Mets]] organizations (1). Six players competed for teams that were unaffiliated with Major League Baseball organizations. ==Key== {| class="wikitable" |- |style="background-color:#BBFFBB;"|{{center|*}} || Indicates multiple award winners in the same year |- | '''Position''' || Indicates the player's primary [[Baseball positions|position]] if known |} ==Winners== [[File:Tommy Glaviano.jpg|thumb|right|[[Tommy Glaviano]], 1946 California League MVP]] [[File:Rocco Baldelli 1.jpg|thumb|right|[[Rocco Baldelli]], 2002 California League MVP]] [[File:MG 7008 Paul Goldschmidt.jpg|thumb|right|[[Paul Goldschmidt]], 2010 California League MVP]] [[File:DSCN0045 Billy Hamilton.jpg|thumb|right|[[Billy Hamilton (baseball, born 1990)|Billy Hamilton]], 2012 California League MVP]] [[File:Corey Seager on September 5, 2015.jpg|thumb|right|[[Corey Seager]], 2014 California League MVP]] [[File:A. J. Reed on August 18, 2016.jpg|thumb|right|[[A. J. Reed]], 2015 California League MVP]] {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center" !scope="col"|Year !scope="col"|Winner !scope="col"|Team !scope="col"|Organization revision.text:
'''Dartitis''' (pronounced dart-eye-tis) is a condition which can affect [[darts]] players, and severely damage their performance. It can be compared to 'the [[yips]]', an expression used to describe apparent loss of fine motor skills without any explanation. The term is used in reference to players who struggle with some kind of [[psychological]] problem with their technique and/or release of their darts. ==Etymology== Dartitis is a [[portmanteau]] of the sport's name and "-itis", a suffix that relates to a medical condition.{{cite web|url=https://www.collinsdictionary.com/dictionary/english/itis|title=Definition of '-itis'|publisher=www.collinsdictionary.com|accessdate=6 April 2018}} It is described by the ''[[Collins English Dictionary]]'' as "(in darts) nervous twitching or tension that destroys concentration and spoils performance".{{cite web|url=https://www.collinsdictionary.com/dictionary/english/dartitis|title=dartitis|publisher=www.collinsdictionary.com|accessdate=6 April 2018}} ==Cases== In 1986 five-times World Champion, [[Eric Bristow]] revealed he had the condition because he was having problems with the release of his darts.{{cite web|title=Eric Bristow interview|url=http://observer.guardian.co.uk/osm/story/0,,1123146,00.html|publisher=The Guardian}} Bristow managed to make a partial recovery from the condition, and even managed to regain the number one position in the [[Darts world rankings|world rankings]]. Former World Champion [[Mark Webster (darts player)|Mark Webster]] also had dartitis.{{cite web|title=World Darts Championship: Mensur Suljovic and Daryl Gurney in Monday action|url=https://news.sky.com/story/world-darts-championship-mensur-suljovic-and-daryl-gurney-in-monday-action-11175037|website=Sky News|accessdate=23 December 2017}} In the [[2017 Grand Slam of Darts]], [[Berry van Peer]] suffered from dartitis. This was visible in his matches against [[Simon Whitlock]], [[Gary Anderson (darts player)|Gary Anderson]] and [[Cameron Menzies]]. ==Condition== Dartitis is believed to be a form of [[dystonia]],{{cite news|url=http://metro.co.uk/2017/11/13/what-is-dartitis-affliction-explained-after-berry-van-peers-grand-slam-of-darts-trauma-7074642/|title=What is dartitis? Affliction explained after Berry van Peer’s Grand Slam of Darts trauma|newspaper=[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]]|date=13 November 2017}} which is described by the UK [[NHS]] as:
A medical term for a range of movement disorders that cause muscle spasms and contractions. The spasms and contractions may either be sustained or may come and go. Movements are often repetitive and cause unusual, awkward and sometimes painful postures. Tremor (shaking) can also be a characteristic of some types of dystonia. Dystonia is thought to be a neurological condition (caused by underlying problems with the brain and nervous system). However, in most cases, brain functions such as intelligence, memory and language remain unaffected.{{cite web|url=https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/dystonia/|title=Dystonia |publisher=www.nhs.uk|accessdate=6 April 2018}}
==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Darts terminology]] {{Darts-stub}}

A '''Formula One World Champion''' is a [[racing driver]] or [[automobile]] [[List of Formula One constructors|constructor]] which has been designated such a title by the governing body of [[Formula One]] - the [[Fédération Internationale de l'Automobile|FIA]]. Every Formula One World Champion since the inaugural [[1950 Formula One season|World Drivers' Championship in 1950]] and the inaugural [[1958 Formula One season|World Constructors' Championship in 1958]] has been awarded the title by accumulating the required points during the course of the F1 season of that particular year, by participating in relevant [[List of Formula One Grands Prix|Grands Prix]].
'''Formula One World Champions''' may refer to:
*[[List of Formula One World Drivers' Champions]] *[[List of Formula One World Constructors' Champions]]
==See also== *[[Formula One]] *[[List of Formula One points scoring systems]] *[[List of Formula One Grands Prix]]
{{Set index article|sports}}
[[Category:Formula One]]

{{distinguish | Gladiator (2000 film)}} {{redirect|Gladiator (1992)|1992 TV series|Gladiators (1992 TV series)}} {{Other uses|Gladiator (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox film | name = Gladiator | image = Gladiator1992.jpg | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Rowdy Herrington]] | screenplay = Lyle Kessler
[[Robert Mark Kamen]] | story = Djordje Milicevic
Robert Mark Kamen | producer = [[Frank Price]]
Stephen J. Roth | starring = {{plainlist| * [[Cuba Gooding Jr.]] * [[James Marshall (actor)|James Marshall]] * [[Robert Loggia]] * [[Ossie Davis]] * [[Brian Dennehy]]}} | music = [[Brad Fiedel]] | cinematography = [[Tak Fujimoto]] | editing = Harry B. Miller III
Peter Zinner | studio = Price Entertainment | distributor = [[Columbia Pictures]] | released = {{Film date|1992|3|6}} | runtime = 101 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = $20 million{{cite web |url=http://powergrid.thewrap.com/project/gladiator-1992 |title=Gladiator (1992) |work=The Wrap |accessdate=February 15, 2014}} | gross = $9.2 million{{cite web |url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=gladiator92.htm |title=Gladiator (1992) |work=Box Office Mojo |accessdate=February 15, 2014}} }} '''''Gladiator''''' is a 1992 American [[List of sports films|sports]] [[Drama (film and television)|drama film]] directed by [[Rowdy Herrington]], and starring [[Cuba Gooding Jr.]], [[James Marshall (actor)|James Marshall]], [[Brian Dennehy]], and [[Robert Loggia]]. The film tells the story of two [[teenager]]s trapped in the world of [[Crime|illegal]] underground [[boxing]]. One is fighting to pay off [[gambling]] debts accumulated by his father. The second is fighting for the money to get out of the [[ghetto]]. While being exploited by a boxing promoter, the two teens become friends. ==Plot== Tommy Riley and his father have just moved to start a new life. Tommy's father has accumulated many gambling debts but has found a new job that requires him to travel extensively, leaving his son alone at home. Tommy also has a hard time fitting in at school, having crossed gang members. He takes a job at a local diner and enters into a romantic relationship with Dawn, the daughter of the owner, but is jumped by the gang members outside the restaurant. Seeing how well Tommy is able to fight, a local boxing promoter by the name of Pappy Jack offers Tommy a chance to fight in an illegal underground boxing operation. When two men arrive announcing that Tommy's father owes a large sum of money to pay off gambling debts, Jack convinces his boss, boxing promoter Jimmy Horn to buy out the debt, which forces Tommy to pay off his father's debts by boxing. Tommy enjoys a great deal of success and develops a friendship with Romano and Abraham "Lincoln" Haines, two fellow fighters. However, he continues to be harassed by gang members, and discovers that two of them, "Black Death" and "Short Cut" are boxers who fight dirty, using elbows, kicks, knees, and low blows, and counting on the crooked refs to overlook the clear violations. Tommy defeats Black Death in the ring, but Short Cut hides a fluid in his gloves, which he uses to blind Romano during a match. Unable to defend himself, Romano is brutally beaten in the ring and is declared brain dead by the doctors. Short Cut later tries the same trick on Tommy, but Tommy has learned to fight dirty, and defeats Short Cut. Meanwhile, Lincoln shows signs of possible brain damage and is told to quit fighting for at least 60 days or else suffer permanent brain damage. Despite this, Horn arranges a match between Lincoln and Tommy. Afraid of killing Lincoln, Tommy takes a beating until the two are unwilling to continue the match. In revenge, Horn, a former boxer who retired undefeated, punches Lincoln severely enough to knock him out of the ring. Furious, Tommy challenges Horn to a match. If Horn wins, Tommy will continue to work for him indefinitely, but if Tommy wins, his father's debt is wiped clean. Horn accepts on the condition that they fight bare-knuckle. Horn's vast experience with boxing initially gives him the upper hand, and Horn's confidence influences him to play with and humiliate Tommy as a result. Tommy eventually uses the various forms of advice he has received throughout his brief boxing experience to outthink Horn: he fakes a broken hand to give Horn even more confidence, and then uses the element of surprise to defeat Horn, freeing himself from Horn's contract. ==Cast== *[[Cuba Gooding Jr.]] as Abraham Lincoln Haines *[[James Marshall (actor)|James Marshall]] as Tommy Riley *[[Robert Loggia]] as Pappy Jack *[[Jon Seda]] as Romano Essadro *[[Brian Dennehy]] as Jimmy Horn *[[Ossie Davis]] as Noah *T. E. Russell as Spits *[[Cara Buono]] as Dawn *[[John Heard (actor)|John Heard]] as John Riley *[[Benny Urquidez]] as Spectator (''uncredited'') *Jesus Rivera as Spectator (''uncredited'') ==Reception== ''Gladiator'' was critically panned.{{cite news | url=http://articles.latimes.com/1992-03-06/entertainment/ca-3273_1_gladiator-movie-tommy | title=Movie Review : 'Gladiator' Packs No Surprise Punches | publisher=The LA Times | date=March 6, 1992 | accessdate=July 14, 2012 | author=Rainer, Peter}}{{cite news | url=https://movies.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=9E0CEEDA123DF935A35750C0A964958260 | title=Gladiator (1992) Review/Film; Corruption And Racial Strife Take Their Toll | publisher=New York Times | date=March 6, 1992 | accessdate=July 14, 2012 | author=Maslin, Janet}}{{cite news | url=http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/19920306/REVIEWS/203060301 | title=Gladiator (1992) | date=March 6, 1992 | accessdate=July 14, 2012 | author=Ebert, Roger | work=Chicago Sun-Times}} On film aggregation website [[Rotten Tomatoes]], it has a 31% rating, with an average score of 4.4/10, based on reviews from 13 critics.{{cite web |url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/1039071-gladiator/ |title=Gladiator (1992) |work=Rotten Tomatoes |accessdate=February 15, 2014}} ==Soundtrack== {{Main|Gladiator (1992 soundtrack)}} {{Unreferenced section|date=February 2015}} A soundtrack containing a blend of hip hop and rock music was released on February 25, 1992 by [[Columbia Records]] It failed to make it to the ''Billboard'' charts, but [[Warrant (American band)|Warrant's]] cover of "[[We Will Rock You]]" was a minor hit on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]], peaking at #83. The soundtrack also contained the last appearance by the rap group, [[3rd Bass]]. [[Jerry Goldsmith]]'s unused score was released by [[Intrada Records]] in 2013, but none of [[Brad Fiedel]]'s retained score appears on the 1992 album. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|0104346|Gladiator}} {{Rowdy Herrington}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gladiator (1992 Film)}} [[Category:1992 films]] [[Category:1990s drama films]] [[Category:1990s teen films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American sports films]] [[Category:American teen drama films]] [[Category:Boxing films]] [[Category:Columbia Pictures films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films set in British Columbia]] [[Category:Films set in Chicago]] [[Category:Underground fighting films]] [[Category:1990s sports films]] [[Category:Films scored by Brad Fiedel]]

==31 January 2006 (Tuesday)== *[[Football (soccer)|Football]]: [[2006 African Cup of Nations]] **Group D: [[Nigeria national football team|Nigeria]] 2–1 [[Senegal national football team|Senegal]] ''Nigeria finishes with a perfect record in the group. Senegal backs into the quarterfinals thanks to Zimbabwe's win over Ghana.'' **Group D: [[Ghana national football team|Ghana]] 1–2 [[Zimbabwe national football team|Zimbabwe]] *[[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] Men's [[College basketball|College Basketball]]: ** (1) [[University of Connecticut|UConn]] 80, (9) [[University of Pittsburgh|Pittsburgh]] 76: ''The [[Harry A. Gampel Pavilion|homestanding]] Huskies, behind 22 points from [[Rudy Gay]], win a physical matchup against the Panthers.'' ** (6) [[University of Illinois at Urbana–Champaign|Illinois]] 66, [[University of Wisconsin–Madison|Wisconsin]] 51: ''For the second straight year, the Fighting Illini go to the Badgers' fortress home court, [[Kohl Center]], and come away with a win. The Illini get 16 points from [[Dee Brown (Illini)|Dee Brown]] and Rich McBride, and take command of the game with a 19–0 run late in the first half. They also take sole possession of the [[Big Ten Conference|Big Ten]] lead.'' ** [[Creighton University|Creighton]] 63, (25) [[University of Northern Iowa|Northern Iowa]] 55: ''The Panthers go [[Qwest Center Omaha|into Omaha]] as a ranked team for the first time, but leave the same way as they have every year since 1996—losing to the Bluejays.''
==30 January 2006 (Monday)== *[[Football (soccer)|Football]]: **[[2006 African Cup of Nations]] ***Group C: [[Tunisia national football team|Tunisia]] 0–3 [[Guinea national football team|Guinea]] ''Guinea makes 3 wins out of 3 in a surprise defeat of the title holders. Both countries progress to the quarter-finals.'' ***Group C: [[Zambia national football team|Zambia]] 1–0 [[South Africa national football team|South Africa]] **[[FA Cup]]: In the fifth round draw, [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] and [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] will meet on the weekend of February 18. *[[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] [[College basketball|College Basketball]]: [[Associated Press|AP]] Polls **Men's: [[University of Connecticut|UConn]], [[Duke University|Duke]], and [[University of Memphis|Memphis]] remain in the top three spots. In other highlights: ***[[The George Washington University|George Washington]] rises to #10, their first top-10 ranking since 1956. ***[[University of Northern Iowa|Northern Iowa]] enters the rankings for the first time ever, at #25. **Women's: As expected, [[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill|North Carolina]] earns its first #1 ranking in history. Duke remains #2. Other highlights: ***[[University of Tennessee|Tennessee]] drops to #5 after losses to Duke and [[University of Kentucky|Kentucky]]. ***Kentucky enters the poll for the first time since 1993, at #21. This is also the first time since 1990 that Kentucky's women have been ranked and their men have not. ***[[St. John's University, New York|St. John's]] enters the poll at #25 after an even longer absence, since 1984.

[http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/index (ESPN)] *[[Tennis]]: [[2006 Australian Open]]: **[[Amélie Mauresmo]] defeats [[Justine Henin-Hardenne]] to win the [[Australian Open]] in [[Melbourne]]. Mauresmo wins the first set 6–1, and leads 2–0 in set 2, when Henin-Hardenne retires because of a stomach ailment. Though it may not be the way she wanted to pick her long-awaited first Grand Slam title, Mauresmo does exact revenge against the [[Belgian]] for her loss in the gold medal final at the [[2004 Summer Olympics]] in [[Athens]], when Henin-Hardenne won gold in straight sets. The retractable roof on the [[Rod Laver Arena]] was closed because of thunderstorms, and birds that had become trapped inside the closed building could be heard chirping during both play and quiet moments in the match. [https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20060128/ap_on_sp_te_ga_su/ten_australian_open_186 (AP/Yahoo!)] **The men's doubles pairing of American twin [[Bob Bryan|Bob]] and [[Mike Bryan]] defeat [[Martin Damm]] ([[Czech Republic|CZE]]) and [[Leander Paes]] ([[India|IND]]) in the final 4–6, 6–3, 6–3. *[[Boxing]]: **Former [[WBO]] world Jr. Welterweight champion [[Randall Bailey]] collapses before a fight. He is taken to a local hospital. His fight is cancelled. [http://articles.news.aol.com/sports/article.adp?id=20060127234809990006&cid=1764] **[[Arturo Gatti]] scores an eleventh round knockout of [[Thomas Damgaard]], in [[Atlantic City, New Jersey]].[http://sports.aol.com/news/articles?id=n20060129000309990024&cid=568]
