====1996-present====
After 1995, the VFA was replaced by the current [[Victorian Football League]] (VFL), which serves as a state league and feeder to the AFL.
{| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Season || Team || Wins || Losses || Draws || Remarks |- | 2001 || [[Bendigo Diggers|Bendigo]] || 0 || 20 || 0 || |- | 2002 || Bendigo || 0 || 19 || 1 || |- | [[2009 VFL season|2009]] || Bendigo || 0 || 18 || 0 || |- | [[2013 VFL season|2013]] || Bendigo || 0 || 18 || 0 || |- | [[2014 VFL season|2014]] || Bendigo || 0 || 18 || 0 || Dropped out of league and folded at the end of the season. |- | [[2015 VFL season|2015]] || [[Frankston Football Club|Frankston]] || 0 || 18 || 0 || |}
==Rugby league==
===Great Britain=== In the [[Rugby Football League Championship]], teams initially played a variable number of games, with the maximum ranging over time from 26 to 38, and some teams playing as few as fourteen. In more modern times the fixture list has been standardised at 26 games per team.
As a result of this fairly lengthy schedule, it has been almost impossible for British rugby league teams to lose all their games, with the only exception being during World War II's so-called "Wartime emergency League" when teams were often able to arrange no more than ten games and some as few as five. The only two winless seasons since normal competition resumed after the war have been in the second and third divisions of the Championship. {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Season || Team || Wins || Losses || Draws || Remarks |- | [[2006 Rugby League National Leagues|2006]] || [[Oldham R.L.F.C.|Oldham]] || 0 || 18 || 0 || National League One<br/>Finished with a points difference of -724 |- | [[1991–92 Rugby Football League season|1991–92]] || [[Mansfield Marksman#Nottingham City RLFC|Nottingham City]] || 0 || 26 || 0 || Third Division<br/>Last season in league<br/> Finished with a points difference of -1159 |- | [[1989–90 Rugby Football League season|1989–90]] || [[Runcorn Highfield RLFC|Runcorn Highfield]] || 0 || 28 || 0 || Second Division<br/>Renamed '''Highfield''' for following season; still took five successive wooden spoons before disbanding in 1997 |- | [[1941–42 Northern Rugby Football League Wartime Emergency League season|1941–1942]] || [[Bramley RLFC|Bramley]] || 0 || 19 || 0 || Left the league until [[1945–46 Northern Rugby Football League season|1945–1946]] |- | [[1940–41 Northern Rugby Football League Wartime Emergency League season|1940–1941]] || [[Broughton Rangers]] || 0 || 10 || 0 || "Wartime Emergency Season"<br/>Left the league until 1945–1946 as '''Belle Vue Rangers''' before disbanding in 1955. |- | 1940–1941 || [[Leigh Centurions|Leigh]] || 0 || 13 || 0 || "Wartime Emergency Season"<br/>Did not return until [[1946–47 Northern Rugby Football League season|1946–1947]] |- | [[1906–07 Northern Rugby Football Union season|1906–1907]] || [[Liverpool City RLFC|Liverpool City]] || 0 || 30 || 0 || Scored only 76 points and conceded almost 1,400. |}
===New South Wales Rugby Football League/National Rugby League=== In the New South Wales Rugby Football League, the ancestor of today’s [[National Rugby League]], seasons were initially between eight (in the event of [[Kangaroo tour]]s) and sixteen games long, so that a very bad team could go through a season with only losses. As a result of the expansion of the NSWRL from 1947 onwards, the season has been lengthened gradually with a few intermissions. The following NSWRFL teams up to 1966 did not win a single game: {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Season || Team || Wins || Losses || Draws || Remarks |- | 1966 || [[Sydney Roosters|Easts]] || 0 || 18 || 0 || Longest winless season in NSWRL/NRL history. Last season with 18 games: in 1967 the season expanded to 22.<br/>Sequence of 29 winless games from Round 13 of 1965. |- | 1946 || [[South Sydney Rabbitohs|Souths]] || 0 || 14 || 0 || Lost 22 successive games after the death of [[Alf Blair]] during the 1944/1945 off-season. |- | 1937 || [[Sydney University rugby league team|University]] || 0 || 8 || 0 || Team disbanded after season shortened by Kangaroo tour, having won only one game in three years (13–11 against St. George in the last round of 1936). |- | 1935 || University || 0 || 16 || 0 || Lost 42 consecutive games after winning 4–3 in opening game of 1934 |- | 1921 || University || 0 || 8 || 0 || Kangaroo tour shortened season.<br/>Won only one game in initial season of 1920 for a combined 1–20 record. |- | 1920 || [[Annandale (rugby league team)|Annandale]] || 0 || 13 || 0 || Disbanded at end of season after having won only one game (8–5 against Norths) in three seasons. |- | 1918 || Annandale || 0 || 14 || 0 || Sequence of 27 winless games: won only twice in last four seasons |} Since 1967, NSWRFL and later NSWRL, ARL and NRL seasons have been between 22 and 26 games long; thus it is much less likely a very bad team could lose every single one of its games.
===Brisbane Rugby League=== The [[Brisbane Rugby League premiership]] began in 1909 and continued in varying forms until 1996, after which it was superseded by the [[Queensland Cup]]. Between the 1930s and the 1960s it was of comparable standard to the New South Wales Rugby Football League, but subsequently a huge drain of players to Sydney eroded the standard of play. Before [[World War II]] seasons were typically no more than twelve games long, so that a very bad team could easily fail to win a game; however as the competition grew it was expanded to 21 games, which made winless seasons much less likely. {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Season || Team || Wins || Losses || Draws || Remarks |- | 1946 || [[Wests Panthers|Western Suburbs]] || 0 || 10 || 0 || Broke its losing streak in the opening game of 1947 but fell to 2–7–1; then won premiership in 1948.<ref>Haddan, Steve; ''Our Game: The Celebration of Brisbane Rugby League 1909-1987'', pp. 126, 128, 131-134 {{ISBN|9780995351202}}</ref> |- | 1945 || [[Eastern Suburbs Tigers|Eastern Suburbs]] || 0 || 10 || 0 || Would rise to minor premiers in 1946 and six straight grand finals 1946 to 1951 via massive recruitment drive.<ref>Haddan; ''Our Game'', p. 125</ref> |- | 1944 || Eastern Suburbs || 0 || 10 || 0 || Two consecutive winless seasons<ref>Haddan; ''Our Game'', p. 118</ref> |- | 1943 || Western Suburbs || 0 || 9 || 0 || Forfeited scheduled tenth match to [[Norths Devils|Northern Suburbs]].<ref>Haddan; ''Our Game'', p. 115</ref> |- | 1940 || Eastern Suburbs || 0 || 10 || 0 || Nine-season record from 1937 to 1945 was 9–81–0.<ref>Haddan; ''Our Game'', p. 106</ref> |- | 1934 || [[Souths Magpies|Southern Suburbs]] || 0 || 11 || 0 || |- | 1933 || Southern Suburbs || 0 || 12 || 0 || Finished last every season from 1933 to 1937 with combined record of 5–48–0, including consecutive winless seasons.<ref>Haddan; ''Our Game'', pp. 83, 87</ref> |- | 1925 || [[Brisbane University rugby league team|University]] || 0 || 9 || 2 || Would finish 7–5 in 1926, but disbanded in middle of 1934 season after all players moved to rugby union. |- | 1915 || West End || 0 || 8 || 0 || Became “Ipswich” the following season, but did not compete after that. |} ==Rugby union== [[Super Rugby]], the Southern Hemisphere's principal club competition, has seen two teams go through an entire season with no wins or draws. Both seasons were in the competition's past incarnations of Super 12 and Super 14, each name reflecting the number of competing teams.
Under both Super 12 ([[1996 Super 12 season|1996]]–[[2005 Super 12 season|2005]]) and Super 14 ([[2006 Super 14 season|2006]]–[[2010 Super 14 season|2010]]) formats, each team played all other teams once, resulting in seasons of 11 and then 13 games. The competition became Super Rugby with the addition of [[Melbourne Rebels|a 15th team]] in [[2011 Super Rugby season|2011]]. The season format was also heavily revamped; the regular season now consists of 16 matches.
The Super 12 and Super 14 eras each saw one team finish a season with only losses; both teams with this dubious distinction are from [[South Africa]]. In [[2002 Super 12 season|2002]], the [[Bulls (Super Rugby)|Bulls]], based in [[Pretoria]], finished with 11 losses from 11 matches. The other imperfect season was that of the [[Johannesburg]]-based [[Lions (Super rugby franchise)|Lions]] in the final season of the Super 14 format in 2010, who lost all 13 of their matches, while ending up with a final points difference of negative 300.
In [[2018 National Rugby Championship|2018]], the [[Sydney Rays]] finished the National Rugby Championship regular season with 0 wins and 0 draws in 7 games.
==Association football== Only three teams are known to have completed a season with no victories or draws. [[Antigua Barracuda F.C.|Antigua Barracuda]] lost all 26 matches of the [[2013 USL Pro season|2013]] [[United Soccer League|USL Pro]], while in the 2015–16 season, English non-league team Longford AFC, played a 30-game season in the Gloucestershire Northern Senior League Division Two (14th tier on the English pyramid), losing all their matches after the majority of their players and manager left. In 2016, [[Grêmio Barueri Futebol|Grêmio Barueri]] lost all 19 matches of the [[Campeonato Paulista Série A3]], the third level of the São Paulo state championship. After the disastrous season, the Antigua and Grêmio Barueri teams folded.
In the [[2010–11 Ukrainian Second League]] (3rd tier on the Ukrainian pyramid), [[FC Veres Rivne]] lost all 14 out of 22 scheduled games before being expelled from the league due to failure of payment of league dues; in addition, they also did not score a single goal at home.
In top-level domestic league football however, few teams have completed their respective seasons without winning a game. In the [[2010–11 Serbian SuperLiga]], [[FK Čukarički Stankom]] played an entire season winless, drawing five matches and losing 25 in a 30-game season, giving them only 5 points and finishing bottom in a field of 16. The team also only scored ten goals whilst conceding 65.
In the [[Bulgarian A Professional Football Group]], which is the top tier of association football in the European country, three teams have all played a season without winning, with those being [[Torpedo Ruse]] (four draws out of 22 matches during [[1951 A PFG|1951]]), [[Rakovski Ruse]] (one draw out of 30 matches during [[1996–97 A PFG|1996/97]]) and [[Chernomorets Burgas Sofia]] (also one draw out of 30 matches during [[2006–07 A PFG|2006/07]]). Chernomorets were however the worse performing out of these, conceding 131 goals with only eight in reply (the same number scored as Rakovski Ruse in their winless season), they still however completed the season with a minus 2 points total, because they violated a rule concerning not being able to field enough youth players.
In the [[1946–47 Allsvenskan]] with 22 games played, [[Billingsfors IK]] tied 3 games and lost 19, the only team in Swedish football history never to win even one single Allsvenskan game in a season.
In the [[1999–2000 Vyshcha Liha]], the highest division of Ukrainian football championship, [[FC Zirka Kirovohrad]] tied 9 matches and lost 21 out of 30.
The open high frequency of draws in association football, coupled with the relatively long length of seasons and [[promotion and relegation]] system used in a majority of jurisdictions to automatically remove the lowest performing teams from any given league, makes winless seasons less likely to occur.
==Netball== In the [[ANZ Championship]], which formed out of the old Commonwealth Bank Trophy in 2008, seasons have been thirteen games. There has so far been one winless season, by the [[Central Pulse]] from [[Wellington]] (formed as a combination [[Capital Shakers|of the Wellington Shakers]] and Western Flyers)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/waikato-times/sport/national-sport/217301 |title=Central Pulse fail to attract Silver Ferns |publisher=Stuff.co.nz |date=2009-01-01 |accessdate=2014-02-18}}</ref> in the opening 2008 season. They did earn one point when a game was abandoned due to a leaking roof. The Pulse were to win only one game each in 2009<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/sport/news/article.cfm?c_id=4&objectid=10581309|title=Netball: Pulse winless no more|date=28 June 2009}}</ref> and 2010, thus having a record of 2–36 after three seasons.
==Cricket== ===County cricket=== {{Main article|Derbyshire County Cricket Club in 1884|Derbyshire County Cricket Club in 1920}} In English [[first-class cricket|first-class]] [[county cricket]], which has a history dating back to the early nineteenth century and was until the middle twentieth century up to the highest standard of the game, seasons have varied in length. Before the 1880s, they were generally less than ten matches in length and some "first-class" counties played only against one or two different opponents, so that a team losing all its games was not uncommon. Between [[1887 English cricket season|1887]] and [[1929 English cricket season|1929]], seasons were gradually increased in length to a standard twenty-eight matches for all counties. However, because of the development and popularity of [[one-day cricket]], seasons have been reduced to twenty-four games in [[1969 English cricket season|1969]] and twenty in [[1972 English cricket season|1972]], though this was increased by two in [[1977 English cricket season|1977]] and [[1983 English cricket season|1983]]. With an increase to four days for all games, sixteen or seventeen games have been played since [[1993 English cricket season|1993]].
Also, because of improvements to pitches via the [[heavy roller]] and covering to protect from rain, the proportion of games "drawn" (not finished) has steadily risen since the 1870s.
Only two county teams have ever finished a season with only losses in a program of eight or more games: {| class="wikitable sortable" |colspan=7|<center>'''English First-Class County Teams Losing Every Game (qualification 8 or more games)'''</center> |- ! Season || Team || Wins || Losses || Draws || Remarks |- | [[1884 English cricket season|1884]] || [[Derbyshire County Cricket Club|Derbyshire]] || 0 || 10 || 0 || Won only three games from 1884 to 1887<br/>Lost every game in 1887, but played only six games |- | [[1920 English cricket season|1920]] || Derbyshire || 0 || 17 || 0 || One match, against [[Nottinghamshire County Cricket Club|Nottinghamshire]], was abandoned without a ball bowled |}
Teams losing ''or'' drawing every game in a first-class county season have been rather less exceptional, though by no means frequent:<ref>Wynne-Thomas, Peter; ''The Rigby A–Z of Cricket Records''; pp. 53 to 67. {{ISBN|072701868X}}</ref> {| class="wikitable sortable" |colspan=7|<center>'''Other English First-Class County Teams with No Wins in a Season (qualification 8 or more games)'''</center> |- ! Season || Team || Wins || Losses || Draws || Remarks |- | [[1865 English cricket season|1865]] || [[Yorkshire County Cricket Club|Yorkshire]] || 0 || 6 || 2 || Were to have an amazing rise due to the discovery of deadly fast bowlers [[George Freeman (cricketer)|Freeman]] and [[Tom Emmett|Emmett]], winning every game [[1867 English cricket season|in 1867]]. |- | [[1871 English cricket season|1871]] || [[Surrey County Cricket Club|Surrey]] || 0 || 9 || 4 || |- | [[1877 English cricket season|1877]] || [[Sussex County Cricket Club|Sussex]] || 0 || 7 || 1 || |- | [[1886 English cricket season|1886]] || [[Derbyshire County Cricket Club in 1886|Derbyshire]] || 0 || 8 || 1 || Was demoted from first-class status between [[1888 English cricket season|1888]] and [[1893 English cricket season|1893]] |- | [[1897 English cricket season|1897]] || [[Derbyshire County Cricket Club in 1897|Derbyshire]] || 0 || 9 || 7 || Lost two games by one wicket to power clubs [[Lancashire County Cricket Club|Lancashire]] and [[Yorkshire County Cricket Club|Yorkshire]] |- | [[1900 English cricket season|1900]] || [[Hampshire County Cricket Club|Hampshire]] || 0 || 16 || 6 || Lost star batsman [[Robert Poore]] to the [[Boer War]] |- | [[1901 English cricket season|1901]] || [[Derbyshire County Cricket Club in 1901|Derbyshire]] || 0 || 13 || 7 || |- | [[1910 English cricket season|1910]] || [[Somerset County Cricket Club|Somerset]] || 0 || 15 || 3 || Lost star bowler [[Bill Greswell]] to business in [[Sri Lanka|Ceylon]].<br/>Two-year record in 1910 and 1911 was one win, 28 losses and five draws |- | [[1924 English cricket season|1924]] || [[Derbyshire County Cricket Club in 1924|Derbyshire]] || 0 || 13 || 11 || |- | [[1928 English cricket season|1928]] || [[Worcestershire County Cricket Club|Worcestershire]] || 0 || 19 || 11 || Most matches and most losses by any winless county team.<br/>Played 54 county matches without a win between June 1927 and May 1929. |- | [[1936 English cricket season|1936]] || [[Northamptonshire County Cricket Club|Northamptonshire]] || 0 || 9 || 15 || Did win one game against [[Sussex County Cricket Club|Sussex]] under “one-innings” rules after first two days washed out by rain |- | [[1937 English cricket season|1937]] || Northamptonshire || 0 || 16 || 8 || Lost star batsman [[Fred Bakewell]] to a car crash and bowler [[Edward Clark (cricketer)|"Nobby" Clark]] to loss of form |- | [[1938 English cricket season|1938]] || Northamptonshire || 0 || 17 || 7 || Ninety-nine [[County Championship]] matches without a win between 14 May 1935 and 29 May 1939 |- | [[1967 English cricket season|1967]] || [[Nottinghamshire County Cricket Club|Nottinghamshire]] || 0 || 4 || 24 || Only team to be winless without finishing bottom<br/>24 drawn matches is most in county cricket history; four finished games is fewest in a season of more than sixteen games |- | [[1979 English cricket season|1979]] || [[Glamorgan County Cricket Club|Glamorgan]] || 0 || 10 || 11 || |- | [[1982 English cricket season|1982]] || [[Warwickshire County Cricket Club|Warwickshire]] || 0 || 8 || 14 || [[Alvin Kallicharran]] was leading run-scorer in country, but bowling exceptionally weak with [[bowling average|average]] of over 45 runs per wicket |- | [[1996 English cricket season|1996]] || [[Durham County Cricket Club|Durham]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cricketarchive.co.uk/Archive/Events/Tables/0/Britannic_Assurance_County_Championship_1996.html |title=The Home of CricketArchive |publisher=Cricketarchive.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2014-02-18}}</ref> || 0 || 12 || 5 || Won only one match in any competition (four-day or one) against a first-class opponent |- | [[2008 English cricket season|2008]] || Surrey || 0 || 5 || 10 || First Division<ref name="LV2008">{{cite web|url=http://www.cricketarchive.co.uk/Archive/Events/Tables/7/LV_County_Championship_2008.html |title=The Home of CricketArchive |publisher=Cricketarchive.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2014-02-18}}</ref> |- | [[2008 English cricket season|2008]] || [[Gloucestershire County Cricket Club|Gloucestershire]] || 0 || 5 || 11 || Second Division<ref name="LV2008"/> |- | [[2009 English cricket season|2009]] || Worcestershire || 0 || 10 || 6 || First Division<ref name="LV2009">{{cite web|url=http://www.cricketarchive.co.uk/Archive/Events/Tables/11/LV_County_Championship_2009.html |title=The Home of CricketArchive |publisher=Cricketarchive.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2014-02-18}}</ref> |- | [[2013 English cricket season|2013]] || [[Leicestershire County Cricket Club|Leicestershire]] || 0 || 8 || 8 || Second Division<ref name="LV2013">{{cite web|url=http://www.cricketarchive.co.uk/Archive/Events/Tables/11/LV_County_Championship_2009.html |title=The Home of CricketArchive |publisher=Cricketarchive.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2014-09-27}}</ref> |- | [[2014 English cricket season|2014]] || Northamptonshire || 0 || 12 || 4 || First Division<ref name="LV2014">{{cite web|url=http://www.cricketarchive.co.uk/Archive/Events/Tables/21/LV_County_Championship_2014.html |title=The Home of CricketArchive |publisher=Cricketarchive.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2014-09-27}}</ref> |- | [[2014 English cricket season|2014]] || Leicestershire || 0 || 10 || 6 || Second Division. First back-to-back winless seasons by a county since the Second World War.<ref name="LV2014"/> |} There were no completely winless seasons in the [[Pro40|Sunday League]] limited-overs competition during its history from 1969 to 2009.
===International first-class cricket=== With the exception of the [[Sheffield Shield]] since the 1970s, most first-class cricket competitions outside England have either been knock-outs or of such short length that it becomes an everyday occurrence for a team to lose all its games. Some, such as the [[Ranji Trophy]] and most seasons of the [[Quaid-e-Azam Trophy]], have indeed been ''knockout'' competitions, which typically use first innings lead to decide if a match is unfinished.
There have still be some notable winless sequences in non-English first-class cricket: * in the 1981–1982 Quaid-e-Azam Trophy, Karachi lost all nine of its matches<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cricketarchive.co.uk/Archive/Events/Tables/2/Quaid-e-Azam_Trophy_1981-82.html |title=The Home of CricketArchive |publisher=Cricketarchive.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2014-02-18}}</ref> * between 1959–1960 and 1986–1987, Jammu and Kashmir played a total of 115 games without a win<ref>Wynne-Thomas; ''The Rigby A−Z of Cricket Records''; p. 68</ref>
===International one-day and Twenty20 cricket=== In the 2012–13 season of the Australian [[Big Bash League]], the [[Sydney Thunder]] completed an imperfect season where they lost all their eight games despite possessing the likes of [[Chris Gayle]]. ==Notes== {{note label|under-age|a|a}}In the [[1944 WANFL season|1944 under-19 wartime competition]] that replaced the senior competition between [[1942 WANFL season|1942]] and that season due to the player drain of World War II, [[South Fremantle Football Club|South Fremantle]] lost all nineteen of their games.

revision.text:
The '''Nike CTR360''' is a line of [[association football|football]] [[football boot|shoes]] manufactured by [[Nike Inc.|Nike]].
==CTR360 Maestri history== In October 2009, Nike released the CTR360 Maestri, when they were debuted on the pitch by [[Cesc Fàbregas]].<ref name=footyboots>{{cite web|url=http://www.footy-boots.com/cesc-fabregas-and-the-ctr360-7931/|title=Cesc Fabregas and the CTR360|accessdate=4 November 2001|publisher=footy-boots.com}}</ref> The name was meant to reference the Italian for "master".<ref name=soccerbible>{{cite web|url=http://www.soccerbible.com/news/football-boots/archive/2009/06/01/nike-ctr360-maestri-football-boots.aspx|title=Nike CTR360 Maestri Football Boots|accessdate=3 November 2011|publisher=soccerbible.com}}</ref> The CTR360 Maestri was created to complement the existing Nike lines of the [[Nike Tiempo|Tiempo Legend]], [[Nike Total 90|Total 90 Laser]] and [[Nike Mercurial Vapor|Mercurial Vapor]]. While the Laser and Vapor are designed for the premier [[Forward (association football)|striker]], the CTR was created for the playmaking [[midfielder]].<ref name=nike>{{cite web|url=http://www.nike.com/nikefootball/bootroom/boots/ctr360?locale=en_US|title=CTR360|accessdate=3 November 2011|publisher=nike.com}}</ref> Upon its launch, the CTR360 was worn by many top football players, such as [[Andrés Iniesta]], [[Mario Balotelli]], [[Javier Mascherano]], [[Sergio Busquets]], [[Florent Malouda]] and [[Alex Song]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.soccerbible.com/news/general/archive/2009/10/04/boot-spotting-nike-ctr360-debut-special.aspx|title=Boot Spotting - Nike CTR360 Debut Special!|accessdate=4 November 2001|publisher=soccerbible.com}}</ref>
Many of the features built into the CTR360 Maestri, were developed to assist players with receiving and distributing the ball, such as dampening pods on the forefoot, and asymmetrical lacing to increase the amount of contact with the ball. To aid distribution, there is a rubberized pass pad on the instep along with memory foam to create a more uniform surface.<ref name=soccerbible/> In order to help improve the player's first touch, Nike developed a new synthetic leather for the boot, called KANGA-LITE. KANGA-LITE is water resistant, similar to other synthetic leathers, but has better ball feel and touch.<ref name=soccerbible/>
The launch of the CTR featured two colorways, Black/Red/White and White/Yellow/Black. Subsequent colorways were White/Royal/Silver/Black/Retro, White/Maroon/Gold, White/Cyber/Black and Black/White/Blue. The CTR360 is available in five different outsoles, FG - firm ground, SG - soft ground, AG - artificial grass, TF - turf and IC - indoor.
==CTR360 Maestri II== [[File:CTR360 Maestri II.JPG|thumb|Nike CTR360 Maestri II White/Silver/Purple colorway]] In December 2010, [[Cesc Fàbregas]] again debuted the new CTR on the pitch against rivals [[Manchester United]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.soccerbible.com/news/general/archive/2010/12/14/fabregas-debuts-nike-ctr360-maestri-ii.aspx|title=Fabregas Debuts Nike CTR360 Maestri II|accessdate=8 November 2011|publisher=soccerbible.com}}</ref> The CTR360 Maestri II was designed to build upon the success of its predecessor while making improvements where necessary. The dampening pods on the forefoot were retained, although they were made larger to offer greater control.<ref name=soccerbible2>{{cite web|url=http://www.soccerbible.com/news/football-boots/archive/2010/12/07/nike-ctr360-amp-ctr360-ii-what-s-the-difference.aspx|title=Nike CTR360 & CTR 360 II - What’s the difference?|accessdate=8 November 2011|publisher=soccerbible.com}}</ref> On the instep, the control pads have gained a fin-like design, similar to that of the T90 Laser III, for added traction.<ref name=soccerbible2/> The memory foam on the instep was replaced by a pass and receive pad featuring grip-like traction, inspired by a golf putter.<ref name=soccerbible2/> The CTR360 Maestri II is available in the same five outsoles as the original. The debut colorway for the boot was Red/White/Black, followed by White/Black/Blue, White/Black/Yellow, Black/White/Red, Platinum/Blue/Black and the current White/Silver/Purple. Nike have also come out with the "clash collection" which provided a new colour way White/Blue/black.
First two color releases in 2012 for the Nike CTR360 Maestri II is Dark Shadow/Volt and Loyal Blue.
==Elite Series== In anticipation of the [[2010 FIFA World Cup|2010 World Cup]] in South Africa, Nike released the Elite Series of football boots. The goal was to create faster versions of their shoes, without compromising their most important qualities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.soccerbible.com/news/football-boots/archive/2010/04/22/nike-elite-world-cup-football-boots.aspx|title=Nike Elite World Cup Football Boots|accessdate=8 November 2011|publisher=soccerbible.com}}</ref> In order to reduce the weight of the CTR, a carbon fiber outsole was added which made the boot 19% lighter.<ref name=soccerbibleelite>{{cite web|url=http://www.soccerbible.com/news/football-boots/archive/2010/05/04/nike-elite-ctr360-maestri-world-cup-football-boots.aspx|title=Nike Elite CTR360 Maestri|accessdate=8 November 2011|publisher=soccerbible.com}}</ref> The original colorway for the Elite series was Metallic Mach Purple/Total Orange. These colors were chosen to make it easier for players to spot each other on the field.<ref name=soccerbibleelite/>
The Elite CTR360 was worn in the World Cup by many players, including [[Mario Balotelli]], [[Carlos Tevez]] and [[Fabio Cannavaro]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.soccerbible.com/news/general/archive/2010/06/07/pre-world-cup-football-boots-spotting.aspx|title=Pre-World Cup Football Boots Spotting|accessdate=8 November 2011|publisher=soccerbible.com}}</ref>
Since the introduction of the Elite Series in May 2010, there has been an Elite version of every colorway of CTR except the current White/Silver/Purple.
== Discontinuation== The successful line was ended by Nike when it announced its new silo, Magistas. <ref>http://www.footyheadlines.com/2013/12/new-nike-magista-2014-boot-leaked-ctr.html</ref> The replacing of CTR360 received a mixed reception. <ref>http://www.footyheadlines.com/2013/12/new-nike-magista-2014-boot-leaked-ctr.html</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==See also== *[[Nike Tiempo]] range, Nike’s ‘Touch’ boot *[[Nike Mercurial Vapor|Nike Mercurial]] range, Nike’s ‘Speed’ boot *[[Nike Total 90]] range, Nike’s ‘Power’ boot

at [[Pepsi Center / Elitch Gardens (RTD)|Pepsi Center/Elitch Gardens]] |website = {{URL|http://www.pepsicenter.com}} }} '''Pepsi Center''' is a multi-purpose [[arena]] located in [[Denver]], [[Colorado]], USA. The arena is home to the [[Denver Nuggets]] of the [[National Basketball Association]] (NBA), the [[Colorado Avalanche]] of the [[National Hockey League]] (NHL), and the [[Colorado Mammoth]] of the [[National Lacrosse League]] (NLL). When not in use by one of Denver's sports teams, the building frequently serves as a concert venue.{{cite web|title=Pepsi Center in Denver, CO|url=http://search.cityguide.aol.com/denver/entertainment/pepsi-center/v-101448627|publisher=AOL City Guide|accessdate=August 22, 2008}}{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} "...Affectionately referred to as "The Can" by some..." The arena is named for its chief [[corporation|corporate]] [[Sponsor (commercial)|sponsor]], [[PepsiCo]].{{cite web |title=About KSE|url=http://www.pepsicenter.com/kse/company/about-kse/|publisher=Kroenke Sports Enterprises|accessdate=June 19, 2007}} ==Construction== Pepsi Center was constructed as part of a large six-year sporting venue upgrade in Denver along with [[Coors Field]], home of the [[Colorado Rockies]], and [[Broncos Stadium at Mile High]] (formerly Invesco Field at Mile High), home of the [[Denver Broncos]]. The complex was constructed to be readily accessible. The arena is situated at Speer Boulevard, a main thoroughfare in downtown Denver, and is served by 2 nearby exits off [[Interstate 25]]. [[Pepsi Center / Elitch Gardens (RTD)|A light rail station]] is on the western side of the complex. Ground was broken for the arena on November 20, 1997, on the {{convert|4.6|acre|m2|adj=on}} site. Its completion in October 1999 was marked by a [[Celine Dion]] concert. Also included in the complex are a basketball practice facility used by the Nuggets, and the Breckenridge Brewery Mountain House''https://www.pepsicenter.com/food-drink/breckenridge-brewery-mountain-house'', a restaurant accessible from within and outside the Center itself. The [[Atrium (architecture)|atrium]] of the building houses a suspended [[sculpture]] depicting various hockey and basketball athletes in action poses. Before the construction of Pepsi Center, the Denver Nuggets and Colorado Avalanche played in [[McNichols Sports Arena]], a building that has since been torn down to serve as a parking lot for nearby [[Broncos Stadium at Mile High]]. Coincidentally, prior to the Avalanche relocating to Denver, the then-[[Quebec Nordiques]] played at another arena to which Pepsi owned naming rights: the [[Colisée Pepsi]]. ==Activity== {{refimprove section|date=May 2009}} [[File:Pepsi Center logo (1999-2009).svg|thumb|Original Pepsi Center logo (1999–2009)]] [[File:Pepsi Center inside.jpg|thumb|Pepsi Center's interior during the 2007 Frozen Four hockey tournament, with the scoreboard used from 1999 to 2013.]] Pepsi Center hosted the [[51st National Hockey League All-Star Game|2001 NHL All-Star Game]], the 2001 [[Stanley Cup]] Finals, and the [[2005 NBA All-Star Game|2005]] [[NBA All-Star Game]]. From 2004 to 2006, the center hosted the [[Mountain West Conference]] [[Mountain West Conference Men's Basketball Tournament|men's basketball tournament]]. The [[National Collegiate Athletic Association]] (NCAA) Men's [[ice hockey]] [[Frozen Four]] West Regional was hosted on March 24 and March 25, 2007. The [[Centrix Financial Grand Prix of Denver]] was held in the parking lot from 2002 to 2006. In 2004, [[Denver|Denver, Colorado]] was selected as one of five cities in the U.S. to host the Dew Action Sports Tour, a new extreme sports franchise that began in 2005. Titled the Right Guard Open, the inaugural event was held at Pepsi Center from July 6 to July 10. The Dew Action Sports returned to Denver for its second year in 2006 during July 13–16. The NCAA Men's [[ice hockey]] [[Frozen Four]] tournament was held at the arena on April 10 and April 12, 2008. Pepsi Center also hosted games of the NCAA Men's Basketball Tournament in 2004, 2008, 2011, and 2016. In 2012, the NCAA Women's [[basketball]] [[NCAA Division I Women's Basketball Championship|Final Four]] was held here. ===Other events=== During the week of July 2–8, 2007, the arena hosted the International Convention and Contests of the [[Barbershop Harmony Society]], a men's singing organization. The arena also hosted the [[2008 Democratic National Convention]], although the party's [[President of the United States|presidential]] [[Nomination|nominee]], then-[[United States Senate|Senator]] [[Barack Obama]], made his acceptance speech at the nearby [[Invesco Field at Mile High]]. To prepare for the convention, Pepsi Center underwent large scale projects including electrical power increases and the installation of new [[transformer]]s by [[Xcel Energy]] (which is the namesake of the [[Xcel Energy Center]] in [[Saint Paul, Minnesota|St. Paul]], which hosted the [[2008 Republican National Convention]] the following week) and telecommunications wiring by [[Qwest]]. A backup generator was installed that has the capacity to power the entire city of [[Pueblo, Colorado]]{{Citation needed|date=April 2016}}. Roughly {{convert|12|mi|km}} of [[optical fiber]] cables were installed for the massive communication needs of the convention. The UFC has hosted four events at the arena.{{cite web |url= http://mmaweekly.com/ufc-president-dana-white-we-always-planned-to-come-back-to-denver |title=UFC President Dana White: We Always Planned to Come Back to Denver |date=July 24, 2011 |publisher=MMAWeekly.com |accessdate=2011-07-24}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ! style="{{NBA color cell|Denver Nuggets|border=2}};"|Event ! style="{{NBA color cell|Denver Nuggets|border=2}};"|Date |- | [[UFC 135]] | Saturday September 24, 2011 |- | [[UFC 150]] | Saturday August 11, 2012 |- | [[UFC on Fox: Shevchenko vs. Peña]] | Saturday January 28, 2017 |- | [[UFC Fight Night: Korean Zombie vs. Rodríguez]] | Saturday November 10, 2018 |} ==Arena enhancements== Prior to the 2013–14 season, the octagonal scoreboard that was in use since the arena's opening was replaced with a new four-sided rectangular scoreboard. The two center faces measure {{convert|27|ft|m}} high by {{convert|48|ft|m}} long, while the two end faces measure {{convert|21|ft|m}} high by {{convert|25|ft|m}} wide. ==Double-booking controversy== [[File:Pepsi Center DNC 2008.jpg|right|thumb|The main entrance to the arena as it looked during the third day of the [[2008 Democratic National Convention]].]] On August 15, 2008, [[WWE|World Wrestling Entertainment]] booked an internationally televised event, ''[[WWE Raw]]'', to take place at Pepsi Center on Monday, May 25, 2009. However, Denver Nuggets and Pepsi Center owner Stan Kroenke arranged a verbal agreement to book Game 4 of the [[2009 NBA Playoffs|NBA Western Conference Finals]] between the Nuggets and the [[Los Angeles Lakers]] on the same date prior to the Nuggets actually earning a slot in the playoffs. Though a contract existed to hold the venue for the WWE event and only a verbal agreement granted the Nuggets the venue, Kroenke stood firm that the Nuggets game would take precedence. WWE chairman [[Vince McMahon]] said, "Even though the Denver Nuggets had a strong team this year and were projected to make the playoffs, obviously Nuggets and Pepsi Center owner Stan Kroenke did not have enough faith in his own team to hold the May 25 date for a potential playoff game."{{cite web |title=WWE vs. Denver Nuggets|url=http://www.wwe.com/inside/news/10250122?cid=2009EP-00|publisher=[[WWE]]|accessdate=May 19, 2009|date=May 18, 2009}} For the WWE event, [[Ticketmaster]] refused to refund their processing fee, thereby only giving fans a partial refund.{{cite news |title=Game 4 on Monday Bumps WWE Event from Pepsi Center|first=Benjamin|last=Hochman|url=http://www.denverpost.com/nuggets/ci_12399761|newspaper=[[The Denver Post]]|date=May 19, 2009|accessdate=February 5, 2013}} The fee, however, is strictly charged by Ticketmaster alone and not WWE or KSE. On May 20, 2009, it was announced that the WWE event scheduled for Pepsi Center would be moved to [[Staples Center]] in [[Los Angeles]] (home of the Nuggets' Western Conference Finals opponent), and return to the Denver area for a non-televised event at the [[Denver Coliseum]] on August 7, 2009, with refunds for the original date made available at points of purchase. ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *{{official website|http://www.pepsicenter.com/}} *{{commonscat-inline|Pepsi Center}} *[http://wheresmyseat.net/pepsi-center-denver-co/ Pepsi Center Seating Chart] {{Navboxes|list1= {{s-start-collapsible|header={{s-sta|et}}}} {{succession box | title = Home of the

{{refimprove|date=July 2015}}
{{Infobox recurring event |name = Port of Dartmouth Royal Regatta |status = Active |genre = [[Regatta]] |frequency = Annually, in August |venue=[[Dartmouth, Devon]], England |founded = 1822 }}
The '''Port of Dartmouth Royal Regatta''' is a [[regatta]] in the English county of [[Devon]]. The first recorded regatta was in 1822 and the regatta was formally established in 1834. It is based on the [[River Dart]], in the town of [[Dartmouth, Devon|Dartmouth]], and the village of [[Kingswear]] opposite.
The regatta takes place over the Thursday, Friday and Saturday where the Friday is the last Friday in August. The regatta is formally opened on the preceding Wednesday evening, although as the regatta has grown, some events start as early as the weekend before.
The regatta is organised by a committee appointed at a public meeting each year called by Dartmouth Town Council. Many other organisations are involved in running events under the auspices of the Regatta Committee.
==History==
The first recorded regatta in Dartmouth was in 1822. There were three sailing races, one six-oared gig race, and a military band played out at the [[Dartmouth Castle]] and 120 attended a ball.
In 1834 the regatta, which used to be run by leading gentlemen of the neighbourhood, changed its format when the inhabitants of the town called a meeting and elected a committee of their own.
In 1856 it became a royal regatta when [[Queen Victoria]], [[Albert, Prince Consort|Prince Albert]] and the [[Edward VII of the United Kingdom|Prince of Wales]] came into Dartmouth in a flotilla of nine boats on an unscheduled visit because of bad weather, arriving the day before the regatta started on 11 August. Prince Albert and his son went up to Sharpham Point in the new steamboat Dartmouth, which had arrived on the river only the previous day. The Queen followed in the state barge, going as far as [[Dittisham]]. The Queen came ashore at 6 pm and was met by the borough mayor. The Queen then drove in a carriage over 'The Ridges' to the 'Black House' at the junction of Jaw Bones/Swannaton Road/Stoke Fleming Road. She was accompanied by Sir H.F. Seale on horseback. That night there were special illuminations both ashore and afloat. The Queen donated £25 and Prince Albert gave £20 for three rowing races to be competed for by the sailors of Dartmouth and this was done on the second day of the regatta. The Queen the next day sailed on to Plymouth but before leaving bestowed the title of 'Royal' on the regatta.
The Committee write each year to the Monarch to request the renewal of the Royal Patronage.
The patron now is [[Prince Andrew, Duke of York|Prince Andrew]], the Duke of York.
==Events==
Although the event is described as a regatta, the charter specifically provides that a regatta should take place on the [[River Dart]] during a fair in the town. To many visitors, the events in the town are more visible, but there is a vast array of events both on and off the water.
===Rowing===
There are two distinct forms of rowing, on two separate days.
The West of England Amateur Rowing Association holds one stage of its championship on the Thursday. This rowing is in [[skiff]]s and [[scull]]s, with competitors from across the West of England and further afield - Bexhill Rowing Club and BTC (Southampton) being present at the 2008 regatta.
On the Friday, the local rowing events take place, where local crews (often representing pubs and clubs from the town) compete over various distances in purpose built rowing boats.
===Air displays===
The regatta has for many years hosted the [[Red Arrows]] RAF display team.
In recent years, displays have also been made by the [[Royal Navy]] [[Westland Lynx|Lynx]] helicopter display team, the [[Black Cats (Royal Navy)|Black Cats]]. In addition, the [[Battle of Britain Memorial Flight]], RAF [[Eurofighter Typhoon|Typhoon]], [[Harrier Jump Jet|Harrier]] and [[SEPECAT Jaguar|Jaguar]] aircraft have displayed, along with RN [[Westland Sea King|Sea King]] and [[Boeing Chinook (UK variants)|Chinook]] helicopters. In recent years it has also had The Royal Artillery parachute display team landing in the river Dart.
===Running===
Organised in association with the Dartmouth Amateur Athletics Club, adult road races to Stoke Fleming (up what is possibly the steepest hill in any regular race, Weeke Hill) and back, and fun races for children are held.
===Tennis===
An [[Lawn Tennis Association|LTA]] recognised tournament is held on the courts in Coronation Park and at the [[Britannia Royal Naval College]], with events covering mixed doubles and the normal singles and doubles matches.
===Sailing===
Four days of events are held in [[Start Bay]], along with fun sailing in the [[River Dart]]. This [[regatta]] is one of the largest [[sailing]] events in the [[United Kingdom]]. The sailing events are organised by the Joint Regatta Sailing Committee ([[Royal Dart Yacht Club]] and Dartmouth Yacht Club) under the auspices of the regatta committee.
===Guardship===
Traditionally, a [[Royal Navy]] vessel attends the regatta as guard ship. In 2008, [[HMS Argyll (F231)|HMS ''Argyll'']] (a type 23 frigate) performed the task, following on from her sister ship [[HMS Somerset (F82)|HMS ''Somerset'']] the previous year. The regatta has also had visits from the navies of [[Belgian Navy|Belgium]], [[French Navy|France]] and [[Armada of the Argentine Republic|Argentina]] ([[ARA Libertad (Q-2)|ARA ''Libertad'']]), among others. The guard ship is open to the public during the regatta, and the crew traditionally take part in a large number of regatta events.
===Street Market===
During the regatta, the road along the river front is closed to allow the street market (known locally as the "Cheap Jacks") to set up in front of the Royal Avenue Gardens. The market is open only on the Wednesday to Saturday of regatta week.
There is also a craft market in a marquee on Coronation Park.
===Steamboat rally===
Usually, a rally of steam powered vessels, all available for inspection throughout the regatta, is organised in conjunction with the [[Steam Boat Association of Great Britain]]. They, with other classic craft, also participate in a review, proceeding down river with a commentary detailing their history.
===Children's events===
Pavement artists, crab fishing and fancy dress competitions all feature.
===Other events===
There are numerous other events including: * Barrel rolling races * Waiters and Waitresses races * The International Trolley Race * Tug of war * A waterborne tug of war (two boats secured together by a rope at the stern with the teams rowing against each other) *Water Polo<ref>http://www.discoverdartmouth.com/festivals-and-events/port-of-dartmouth-royal-regatta-p1511953</ref>
===Fireworks===
There are two fireworks displays, on the Thursday and Saturday nights.
===Music===
Throughout the week there are public performances in the bandstand in the Royal Avenue Gardens. There is a rock concert at the beginning of the week.
There are also recitals in the local churches.
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.dartmouthregatta.co.uk/ Regatta website] * [http://www.dartmouthweek.com/ Sailing Regatta website] * [http://www.dartmouthathletics.co.uk/ Dartmouth Amateur Athletics Club] * [http://www.dartmouthyc.org.uk/ Dartmouth Sailing Club]

{{unreferenced|date=May 2015}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Prachinburi Provincial Administrative Organization Stadium | image = | location = [[Prachinburi province|Prachinburi]], [[Thailand]] | coordinates = {{coord|14.0646206|101.3749326|format=dms|type:landmark_scale:3000}} | opened = | owner = | operator = | surface = [[Grass]] | construction_cost = | former_names = | tenants = [[Prachinburi United F.C.]] 2010
[[Prachinburi F.C.]] 2010 | seating_capacity = 3,000 }} '''Prachinburi Provincial Administrative Organization Stadium''' ({{lang-th|สนาม อบจ.ปราจีนบุรี หรือ สนามกีฬาจังหวัดปราจีนบุรี}}) is a [[multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Prachinburi province]], [[Thailand]]. It is currently used mostly for [[football (soccer)|football]] matches and is the home stadium of [[Prachinburi United F.C.]]. The stadium holds 3,000 people. {{coord|14.0646206|101.3749326|type:landmark_region:TH|display=title}} [[Category:Football venues in Thailand]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in Thailand]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Prachinburi Province]] [[Category:Sport in Prachinburi Province]] {{Thailand-sports-venue-stub}}

revision.text:
{{National rugby union | unionname = Rugby Federation of Armenia | nativename = Hajastani Regbii Federatsia | logo = Armenie-rugby.JPG | logosize = 200px | founded = 2000 | region = [[Rugby Europe]] | regionyear = 2002  {{right|Associate Member}}
{{right|(suspended in 2014)}} | president = Yuri Beglaryan11 | coach = Laurent Hairabetian (player-coach) | womenscoach = | url = {{url|https://web.archive.org/web/20131021134311/http://www.armrugby.am/home- eng.htm|www.armrugby.am}} (archived) }} The '''Rugby Federation of Armenia''' ({{lang-hy|'''Հայաստան Ռեգբիի ֆեդերացիա''', Hajastani Regbii Federatsia}}; {{lang-ru|'''Федерация регби Армении''', Federatsiya Regbi Armenii}}) is the governing body for [[rugby union]] in [[Armenia]]. It was founded in 2000 and joined FIRA-AER (now [[Rugby Europe]]) as an associate member in 2002. Rugby Europe suspended the Rugby Federation of Armenia in November 2014 due to inactivity. ==History== Rugby was first played in the country in the 1960s, when Armenia was a republic within the [[Soviet Union]]. Armenia had its own representative team within the USSR, although it was not considered to be a proper national side. Armenian clubs including Yerevan Dinamo RC and Yerevan Spartak RC played in the top division of [[Soviet Championship (rugby union)|Soviet Championship]] and [[Soviet Cup (rugby)|Soviet Cup]]. The rugby teams were disbanded due to the effects of the [[Nagorno-Karabakh War|Armenia-Azerbaijan War]] and economic difficulties in Armenia during first years of independence in the early 1990s. Rugby in Armenia went into hibernation for almost a decade until the founding of the Rugby Federation of Armenia (RFA) in 2000. Gagik Panikian become the RFA president in 2002 and the RFA joined FIRA-AER (now [[Rugby Europe]]) later that year. National teams for sevens and fifteen-a-side were soon formed to play in European competitions. As of 2012, there were three rugby clubs in Armenia: Ararat, Artashat, and Ureni. Rugby Europe suspended the Rugby Federation of Armenia due to inactivity in 2014. ==National teams== *[[Armenia national rugby union team|Armenia]] - the national men's rugby union team was formed in 2004 and was largely drawn from players of Armenian heritage in France. The team played at the 2004 European Championships, defeating {{nrut|Norway}} and {{nrut|Israel}}. *[[Armenia national rugby union team (sevens)|Armenia 7s]] - the national men's rugby union seven-a-side team was formed in 2003. ==See also== *[[Armenia national rugby union team]] *[[Rugby union in Armenia]] ==References== {{reflist|refs= {{cite web |date= 21 January 2012 |title= Robert Melkonyan: Reviving the traditions of Armenian rugby |work= Azad-Hye |accessdate= 31 January 2015 |url= http://www.azad-hye.net/news/viewnews.asp?newsId=350agdg19 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20150130195107/http://www.azad-hye.net/news/viewnews.asp?newsId=350agdg19 |archivedate= 30 January 2015}} {{cite web |date= 21 November 2014 |title= World Rugby gives Cyprus warm welcome but Armenia and Greece the cold shoulder |url= http://rugbyredefined.com/2014/11/21/world-rugby-gives-cyprus-warm-welcome-but-armenia-and-greece-the-cold-shoulder/ |publisher=ASOIF |accessdate= 2016-10-20}} }} ==External links== '''Official site:''' *{{en icon}} {{hy icon}} {{ru icon}} {{cite web |title= Rugby Federation of Armenia |url= http://www.armrugby.am/home-eng.htm |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20131021134311/http://www.armrugby.am/home-eng.htm |archivedate= 21 October 2013 }} *{{hy icon}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20070928083200/http://www.armrugby.am/index.htm Rugby Federation of Armenia ] '''Other sites:''' *{{hy icon}} {{en icon}} {{ru icon}} [http://armrugby.do.am Armenian Rugby Supporters website (Հայերեն, in English, на Русском)] {{dead link|date=January 2015}} *{{fr}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20150131053742/http://www.lestimbresdurugby.com/Archivesdurugby/Pays/Armenie.htm Archives du Rugby: Armenie] {{Sports governing bodies in Armenia}} {{IRB Unions}} First played in 1999–2000 and won by [[Al-Hilal FC|Al-Hilal]].[http://www.alriyadh.com/Contents/2000/02/17-02-2000/page2.html#1 Al-Hilal win the Saudi Founder's Cup''' ] {{ar icon}} ==Final Match== {{footballbox |date=16 February 2000 |time=19:20 |team1=[[Al-Hilal FC|Al-Hilal]] |team2=[[Al-Ahli (Jeddah)|Al-Ahli]] |score=2–1 |goals1=[[Nawaf Al-Temyat]] {{goal|}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Sullivan Athletic Center| nickname = | image = McGrath-Phillips Arena.jpg | location = 2323 N Sheffield
Chicago, IL 60604 USA| broke_ground = 1999| opened = May 2000| closed = | demolished = | owner = [[DePaul University]]| operator = DePaul University| surface = | construction_cost= | architect = | former_names = | tenants = [[DePaul Blue Demons]] ([[NCAA]]) (2000–present)| seating_capacity = 3,000 }} '''Sullivan Athletic Center''' is a 3,000-seat multi-purpose [[arena]] on the campus of [[DePaul University]] in [[Chicago]], in the [[U.S. state]] of [[Illinois]]. It is the home arena for the women's volleyball team and part-time home for the women's basketball team. ==History== The arena originally named the DePaul Athletic Center opened in 2000, replacing [[Alumni Hall (DePaul University)|Alumni Hall]]. It was a part-time home to the DePaul [[DePaul Blue Demons men's basketball|men's basketball]] team from 2000 to 2017. From 2000 to 2017 it was the full-time home of the [[DePaul Blue Demons women's basketball|women's basketball]] team and since 2017 it has served as part-time home for the women’s team. The volleyball team has played all their home game here since it’s opening in 2000. The DePaul Athletic Center was renamed the Sullivan Athletic Center in 2006. It houses both McGrath-Phillips Arena the home of the women's volleyball team as well as the DePaul athletic department. In 2010, the court was named after the longtime coach of the women's basketball team, [[Doug Bruno]]. It served as the host of the 2002 [[Conference USA]] women's basketball tournament. ==See also== *[[DePaul Blue Demons]] ==References== {{reflist|refs= {{cite news|last=|first=|title=2015-16 Women's Basketball CUSA|date=|url=http://grfx.cstv.com/photos/schools/c-usa/sports/w-baskbl/auto_pdf/2015-16/misc_non_event/media-guide.pdf|newspaper=|accessdate=5 Dec 2015}} {{cite web|last1=|first1=|title=DePaul names court after Doug Bruno|date=Nov 6, 2010|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/chicago/news/story?id=5774912|website=ESPN|accessdate=16 Dec 2015}} }} {{Coord|41.923901|-87.653167|type:landmark|display=title}} {{DePaul University}} {{DePaul Blue Demons women's basketball navbox}} [[Category:Basketball venues in Chicago]] [[Category:Defunct college basketball venues in the United States]] [[Category:College volleyball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Volleyball venues in Chicago]] [[Category:DePaul Blue Demons basketball venues]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2000]] [[Category:2000 establishments in Illinois]] {{Illinois-sports-venue-stub}} {{Chicago-struct-stub}}

{{Orphan|date=June 2016}} {{Infobox Organization |fullname = United States Footvolley |organizationname = USA Footvolley |abbreviation = USA-F |image = |caption = |motto = Build the base,
Promote the sport,
Achieve competitive success |formation = 2003 |extinction = |type = [[Sports governing body|National governing body (NGB)]] |status = |purpose = Organizing competitive footvolley in the USA |headquarters = [[Sunny Isles Beach, Florida|Sunny Isles Beach, FL, USA]] |region_served = United States |membership = 2,000+ |language = English |leader_title = Executive Director |leader_name = Sergio Menezes |main_organ = |parent organization = |affiliations = |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = www.usafootvolley.org |remarks = }} '''USA Footvolley''' is the national [[Sport governing body|governing body]] for [[Footvolley]] in the [[United States]]. It is in charge of selecting the United States Footvolley team and any other teams which officially represent the United States, as well as the overall organization and operation of the sport within the country, in accordance with the Amateur Sports Act. The national headquarters is located in [[Sunny Isles Beach]], [[Florida]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.accessmylibrary.com/article-1G1-143726711/footvolley-hot-sport-south.html |title=Footvolley hot sport in South Beach: |accessdate=2010-01-29 |last=Woods |first=Casey |date=March 27, 2006 |work=[[Miami Herald]] |publisher=Miami Herald }}{{cite news |title=Footvolley’s popularity taking off in South Florida|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/living/health-fitness/article51001670.html|publisher=[[Miami Herald]]}} ==History== Footvolley was created by Octavio de Moraes in 1965{{Cite web|url=http://www.footvolley.net/news.php?nsid=17 |title=Birthplace of Footvolley to Host Olympic Games! |accessdate=2010-01-29 |work=Pro Footvolley Tour, LLC }} in [[Rio de Janeiro]]'s [[Copacabana (Rio de Janeiro)|Copacabana Beach]]. The game of footvolley - first called 'pevoley', literally meaning "footvolley", that was discarded for "futevôlei". Footvolley started in Rio de Janeiro; however cities like [[Recife]], [[Salvador, Bahia|Salvador]], [[Brasília]], [[Goiânia]], [[Santos, São Paulo|Santos]] and [[Florianópolis]] have players who have been playing footvolley since the 1970s. Teams of footvolley had five a side at first. Due to the skill level of the footvolley athletes (nearly all were professional football players), the ball would rarely drop. The players began lowering the number of players on each side, eventually settling on 2 versus 2, which is still in use today.{{Cite web|url=http://www.futevolei.com.br/Historia.html |title=Futevolei Historia |accessdate=2010-01-29 |work=Futevolei.com.br }} ''[https://translate.google.com/translate?hl=en&sl=pt&u=http://www.futevolei.com.br/Historia.html&ei=9zljS9ukC4eXtgepss24Bg&sa=X&oi=translate&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CBAQ7gEwAA&prev=/search%3Fq%3Dhttp://www.futevolei.com.br/Historia.html%26hl%3Den%26safe%3Doff%26sa%3DG%26num%3D50 English translation]'' The first International Footvolley event to occur outside of Brazil was in 2003 by the United States Footvolley Association on Miami Beach at the 2003 Fitness Festival. Brazilian athletes: Wellington Correa 'Helinho' and Renan were the Champions of the competition; but the sport gained steam for international development. In 2016, the City of Sunny Isles Beach, FL provided USA Footvolley its Official Training Centre. Here is where the National Team trains. ==Organizational structure== There are several parts and levels that make up USA Footvolley. There is the National governing body (national) level, the Zone (regional) level, and the Local Footvolley Committee (local/state) level. ===Pro Footvolley Tour rules=== The rules in the [[United States]] professional tour [[Pro Footvolley Tour]] are designed to make the matches faster and more aggressive. Some of the notable differences are: net height of 2.10 Meters; 2-pointers are awarded up to 3-times maximum per set for all shots scored with the foot when one foot goes above the head when striking the ball and the other foot is off the ground (bikes, matrix kicks, etc.){{cite news |title=Pro Footvolley Tour |url=http://wlrn.org/post/shark-attack-beach-footvolleys-popularity-taking-florida-us// |publisher=[[wlrn]]}} Pro Footvolley Tour airs on Root Sports, Comcast SportsNet, Time Warner SportsChannel, Bright House Networks, WapaDeportes, and CaribVision. Through DirecTV Pro Footvolley Tour can be seen in the entire United States and Puerto Rico.{{cite news |title=Explore DirectTV |url=https://www.directv.com/tv/Pro-Footvolley-Tour-c01jckE2UEpKYms9/Episode-UW5ZWjRPRVVvQkhRZzFtanlJaWJPZz09 |publisher=[[DirectTV]]}}{{cite news |title=Comcast |url=http://corporate.comcast.com/images/sportsnet-houston1.pdf |publisher=[[Comcast NBC Universal]]}} ===National Championship/US Open=== The National Championship is exactly what the name implies. There is only 1 National Championship meet at the conclusion of each season across the country. The National Championships are also of the invitational meet format and offer extremely high level competition. Only a very small percentage of people who ever play footvolley will make it to this high a level of competition. This meet is generally used to determine the US National Team for various international level meets each year, but is not used to determine the US Olympic Team. ===US Olympic Trials=== The United States Olympic Trials will be held for the first time on June 25 in [[Seaside, Oregon]]. This event will be held once every 4 years. Since this meet offers such a coveted prize (a spot on the US Olympic Team) for the 2016 Rio Olympics exhibition tournament. United States citizenship is required to compete at this meet since only United States citizens are allowed to represent the United States at the Olympics. The Olympic Trials are also under unique requirements made by the [[United States Footvolley Association|USFA]]. Trials meets are also held for the World Championships and World University Games, typically at a national championship meet. ==See also== {{Portal|Footvolley}} *[[United States Sports]] *[[Pro Footvolley Tour]] *[[Ginga Scout]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.usafootvolley.org/ USA Footvolley] {{Sports governing bodies of the United States}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Usa Footvolley}} [[Category:Sports governing bodies in the United States|Swimming]] [[Category:Sports rules and regulations]] [[Category:Organizations based in Miami]] [[Category:Sports in Miami]] [[Category:Sports organisations established in 2003]] [[Category:2003 establishments in Florida]]

{{Infobox film | name = Whip It | image = Whip It (2009 film) poster.jpg | alt = | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Drew Barrymore]] | producer = Drew Barrymore
[[Barry Mendel]] | screenplay = [[Shauna Cross]] | based on = {{based on|''[[Derby Girl]]''|Shauna Cross}} | starring = {{ubl|[[Ellen Page]]|[[Marcia Gay Harden]]|[[Kristen Wiig]]|Drew Barrymore|[[Juliette Lewis]]|[[Jimmy Fallon]]|[[Daniel Stern (actor)|Daniel Stern]]}} | music = [[The Section Quartet]] | cinematography = [[Robert D. Yeoman]] | editing = [[Dylan Tichenor]] | studio = [[Mandate Pictures]]
Vincent Pictures
[[Flower Films]]
Rye Road Productions
Babe Ruthless Productions
[[Barry Mendel Productions]]
[[Dune Entertainment]] | distributor = [[Fox Searchlight Pictures]] | released = {{Film date|2009|9|13|[[Toronto International Film Festival]]|2009|10|2|United States}} | runtime = 110 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = $15 million | gross = $16.6 million }} '''''Whip It''''' is a 2009 American [[Sports film|sports]] [[comedy-drama film]] directed by [[Drew Barrymore]] in her [[directorial debut]] and written by [[Shauna Cross]], based on her novel ''[[Derby Girl]]''. The film is co-produced by Barrymore and [[Barry Mendel]]. It stars [[Ellen Page]] as a teenager from the fictional town of Bodeen, [[Texas]], who joins a [[roller derby]] team. The film also stars Barrymore, [[Alia Shawkat]], [[Marcia Gay Harden]], [[Daniel Stern (actor)|Daniel Stern]], [[Carlo Alban]], [[Landon Pigg]], [[Jimmy Fallon]], [[Kristen Wiig]], [[Zoë Bell]], [[Eve (rapper)|Eve]], [[Andrew Wilson (actor)|Andrew Wilson]], [[Juliette Lewis]], and [[Ari Graynor]]. The film premiered at the [[Toronto International Film Festival]] on September 13, 2009 and was theatrically released on October 2, 2009 in the United States by [[Fox Searchlight Pictures]]. It received generally positive reviews from critics but did not perform well financially, having made $16.6 million worldwide against its $15 million budget.{{cite web|last1=Flint|first1=Joe|title=Whip It' didn't need to get whipped at box office|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/entertainmentnewsbuzz/2009/10/whip-it-didnt-need-to-get-whipped-at-box-office.html|publisher=LA Times|accessdate=3 July 2014|date=26 October 2009}} It received two WIN Award nominations for Outstanding Actress, as well as Feature Film for Page and Barrymore, respectively. ''Whip It'' was released on DVD and Blu-ray on January 26, 2010 by [[20th Century Fox Home Entertainment]]. The movie has inspired many people to start playing roller derby, including several current top-level players like [[Scald Eagle]].{{cite web|title=October 2015 Featured Skater:Scald Eagle - Featured Skaterof the Month - Women’s Flat Track Derby Association|url=https://wftda.org/featured-skater/scald-eagle|website=wftda.org|publisher=WFTDA|accessdate=9 March 2018|date=1 October 2015}} ==Plot== Bliss Cavendar ([[Ellen Page]]) is a misfit in the small town of Bodeen, [[Texas]], with no sense of direction in her life. Her mother, Brooke ([[Marcia Gay Harden]]), a former beauty queen, pushes her to enter beauty pageants despite her lack of interest. During a shopping trip to Austin with her mother, Bliss encounters three [[roller derby]] team members and finds herself intrigued by the sport in which teams and players are given pun names that highlight the violent aspect of the sport. Intrigued, she and her friend Pash ([[Alia Shawkat]]) attend a roller derby bout under the pretense of going to a football game, where they see the "Holy Rollers" defeat the "Hurl Scouts", a perennially unsuccessful derby team. Returning to [[Austin, Texas|Austin]], Bliss lies about her age and tries out for the Hurl Scouts, discovering her natural skating abilities in the process. Joining the team, Bliss is given the [[derby name]] "Babe Ruthless." After realizing she needs to be merciless in roller derby, Bliss sees she needs to take charge in other aspects of her life. One involves Bliss's love interest, a lanky young rock guitarist and singer named Oliver ([[Landon Pigg]]) whom she meets via her exposure to roller derby. They enjoy a whirlwind romance before Oliver leaves for a tour, taking a T-shirt Bliss gave him to remember her by, in exchange for his jacket. She later finds a picture of him at a gig with another girl, who is wearing her T-shirt. She burns his jacket in retribution and subsequently breaks up with him following his return, although he vehemently denies that anything happened. Another sub-plot examines Bliss's relationship with her parents, a loving but controlling mother and an amiable but clueless father ([[Daniel Stern (actor)|Daniel Stern]]) who seldom opposes his wife's parental decisions. After seeing her excelling and enjoying roller derby, Bliss's father convinces her mother to let Bliss out of a pageant (which is at the same time as the championship roller derby game) and convinces the Hurl Scouts to come get Bliss for the bout. Various other sub-plots include her relationship with Pash, and confrontations with a stuck up snob at school. Pash is fine with Bliss's new path, until she gets arrested with an open container of beer while she is waiting for Bliss, who has left to go find Oliver. Eventually, Pash gets together with their manager and forgives Bliss. The movie ends with the Hurl Scouts narrowly losing the championship match and everyone finally getting along; the team chants "We're number two!" which was the same thing they chanted when they lost their first match. ==Cast== * [[Ellen Page]] as Bliss Cavendar (Babe Ruthless) * [[Alia Shawkat]] as Pash * [[Marcia Gay Harden]] as Brooke Cavendar * [[Daniel Stern (actor)|Daniel Stern]] as Earl Cavendar * [[Carlo Alban]] as Dwayne (Birdman) * [[Landon Pigg]] as Oliver * [[Jimmy Fallon]] as 'Hot Tub' Johnny Rocket * [[Kristen Wiig]] as Maggie Mayhem * [[Zoë Bell]] as Bloody Holly * [[Eve (rapper)|Eve]] as Rosa Sparks * [[Drew Barrymore]] as Smashley Simpson * [[Andrew Wilson (actor)|Andrew Wilson]] as Razor * [[Juliette Lewis]] as Iron Maven * [[Ari Graynor]] as Eva Destruction * [[Har Mar Superstar]] as Fight Attendants Coach ==Production== ===Production and filming=== Screenwriter [[Shauna Cross]] [[film adaptation|adapted]] her 2007 [[young adult fiction|young adult novel]] ''[[Derby Girl]]'' for the screen and pitched the script to different production companies while simultaneously pitching its source material to various publishers. Once Barrymore got involved, she and Cross worked for months on script revisions, with Barrymore pushing her to "avoid her story's tidier prospects, to make things 'more raw and open-ended.'"{{cite news| url= https://www.nytimes.com/2009/09/27/movies/27alme.html |title= Stepping Into the Skates of the Director |date= September 23, 2009| first = Michael |last=Almereyda | work= [[The New York Times]]| accessdate= 2011-06-30}} The film project was initially to be handled by [[Warner Independent Pictures]], but [[Mandate Pictures]] took over after it was put into a [[Turnaround (filmmaking)|turnaround]].{{cite news |url = http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117987712.html |title = Shauna Cross |date = 2008-06-18 |accessdate = 2008-06-30 |work = [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |publisher = Reed Business Information |author = Swart, Sharon}} [[Filmmaking#Production|Production]] began summer 2008 in [[Michigan]]; [[principal photography]] began on July 26, taking place in and around [[Detroit]], [[Saline, Michigan|Saline]], [[Ypsilanti, Michigan]] and [[Birch Run, Michigan|Birch Run]]. Real roller derby players were selected from local Michigan teams such as the [[Detroit Derby Girls]], and the [[Grand Raggidy Roller Girls]].{{cite news |url = http://blog.mlive.com/grpress/2008/08/grand_rapids_skaters_roll_em_i.html |title = Grand Rapids skaters roll 'em in Drew Barrymore movie "Whip It!" |author = Serba, John |date = 2008-08-10 |work = The Grand Rapids Press |publisher = MLive.com |accessdate = 2008-08-12}} Several scenes were also shot in Austin, [[Texas]].{{cite news|url=http://www.variety.com/VR1117979134.html|title=Ellen Page to 'Whip It!' for Barrymore| date=2008-01-15| accessdate=2008-06-30| work= [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] | publisher=Reed Business Information|last=Siegel|first= Tatiana}}{{cite news| url= http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/hr/content_display/film/news/e3i17cfb9d2f397c8cb48a75eaa6bee886c| title=Cast ready to roll on 'Whip It!'|date=2008-06-30|accessdate=2008-06-30|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |publisher=Nielsen Business Media|author1=Goldstein, Gregg |author2=Kit, Borys |lastauthoramp=yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080702233216/http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/hr/content_display/film/news/e3i17cfb9d2f397c8cb48a75eaa6bee886c |archivedate = 2008-07-02}} Some scenes were also shot in Hamtramck, Michigan at Hamtramck High School as well as Ferndale, Michigan at Ferndale High School. ''Whip It'' was produced by [[Barry Mendel]] and [[Drew Barrymore]]; a co-production between [[Mandate Pictures]] and Barrymore's [[Flower Films]]. The film was distributed by [[Fox Searchlight Pictures]]. ===Casting=== On August 12, 2009, it was announced that [[Ellen Page]] would play the lead role in the film, while [[Alia Shawkat]], [[Marcia Gay Harden]], [[Daniel Stern (actor)|Daniel Stern]] and [[Carlo Alban]] were in early talks to join the cast. On August 14, 2009, [[Landon Pigg]], [[Jimmy Fallon]], [[Kristen Wiig]], [[Zoë Bell]], [[Eve (rapper)|Eve]], [[Drew Barrymore]] and [[Andrew Wilson (actor)|Andrew Wilson]] were also in final talks to join the film, [[Juliette Lewis]] was added to the cast, playing Iron Maven (a play on [[Iron Maiden]]) and on August 18, 2009, [[Ari Graynor]] and [[Har Mar Superstar]] joined the cast of the film, playing Eva Destruction (a play on [[Eve of Destruction (song)|Eve of Destruction]]) and the Fight Attendants Coach. ''Whip it'' is the feature-film debut of Pigg. ===Music=== [[The Section Quartet]] scored the music for the film and on its soundtrack. The soundtrack also contains "Knocked Up" performed by Kings Of Leon, "Pot Kettle Black" performed by [[Tilly and the Wall]], "[[Sheena Is a Punk Rocker]]" performed by [[Ramones]], "What's the Altitude" performed by [[Cut Chemist]] and Hymnal, "Bang On" performed by [[The Breeders]], "Dead Sound" performed by [[The Raveonettes]], "Blue Turning Grey" performed by [[Clap Your Hands Say Yeah]], "Your Arms Around Me" performed by [[Jens Lekman]], "[[Learnalilgivinanlovin]]" performed by [[Gotye]], "[[Boys Wanna Be Her]]" performed by [[Peaches (musician)|Peaches]], "[[Jolene (song)|Jolene]]" performed by [[Dolly Parton]], "[[Caught Up in You]]" performed by [[38 Special (band)|38 Special]], "[[Never My Love]]" performed by [[Har Mar Superstar]] and [[Adam Green (musician)|Adam Green]], "Black Gloves" performed by [[Goose (band)|Goose]], "Crown of Age" performed by [[The Ettes]], "High Times" performed by [[Landon Pigg]] and Turbo Fruits, "Unattainable" performed by [[Little Joy]], "Doing it Right" performed by [[The Go! Team]], "Breeze" performed by [[Apollo Sunshine]], "[[Kids (MGMT song)|Kids]]" performed by [[MGMT]], "Fun Dream Love Dream" performed by Turbo Fruits, "Know How" performed by [[Young MC]], "The Road to Austin" performed by The Section Quartet, "[[No Surprises]]" performed by [[Radiohead]], "Domingo no Parque" performed by [[Gilberto Gil]], "Lollipop" performed by [[Squeak E. Clean]] and Desert Eagles and other songs performed by other song performers. ==Release== ===Theatrical release=== ''Whip It'' was theatrically released on October 2, 2009 in the United States. [[Fox Searchlight Pictures]] distributed the film to 1,721 screens in the United States. ===Premiere=== [[Image:ToRD at Whip It premiere.JPG|thumb|right|180px|[[Toronto Roller Derby]] skaters play an exhibition bout at the [[Toronto International Film Festival]] premiere of ''Whip It'', September 13, 2009]] The world premiere of the film was held at the 2009 [[Toronto International Film Festival]] in [[Toronto]], Ontario, Canada.{{cite news|last=Block|first=Sheri|title=Barrymore whips up excitement for roller derby flick|url=http://www.ctv.ca/servlet/ArticleNews/story/CTVNews/20090913/tiff_whipit_090913/20090913?s_name=tiff2009%20Barrymore%20whips%20up%20excitement%20for%20roller%20derby%20flick|accessdate=6 February 2012|newspaper=CTV News|date=13 September 2009}} The majority of the film's main cast attended the premiere. As part of the festivities, members of local league [[Toronto Roller Derby]] held an exhibition bout at [[Yonge Dundas Square]] in downtown Toronto. Toronto Roller Derby skaters, like those in other cities with major roller derby leagues, also helped promote the film in advance of the screening by wearing costumes from the film and skating around town and performing stunts while handing out flyers and giveaway items. Toronto Roller Derby credits their luck in being able to skate at the festival for helping expand their fanbase as well as their skater rosters.{{cite web|title=2009 championship bout!|url=http://torontorollerderby.com/blog/?p=30|work=November 21, 2009|accessdate=February 6, 2012}} ===Home media=== ''Whip It'' was released on DVD and Blu-ray in January 26, 2010 by [[20th Century Fox Home Entertainment]]. ==Reception== ===Critical response=== [[File:Eve Whip It TIFF09.jpg|thumb|right|[[Eve (rapper)|Eve]] was praised by critics for her performance.]] Critical reception for ''Whip It'' was generally positive; based on 182 reviews collected by [[Rotten Tomatoes]], the film has an overall approval rating from critics of 84%, with an [[weighted mean|average]] score of 7/10.{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/whip_it/|title=Whip It Movie Reviews|work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|publisher=[[Fandango Media]] | accessdate= April 10, 2018}} [[Metacritic]] calculated an average score of 68, based on 31 reviews.{{cite web| url= http://www.metacritic.com/movie/whip-it|title=Whip It Reviews|work=[[Metacritic]]| publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |accessdate=October 11, 2009}} [[A. O. Scott]] called the film "predictable", but said "You might, nonetheless, want to see this movie, even—or maybe especially—if you have seen ''[[Billy Elliot]]'' or ''[[Bend It Like Beckham]]''. Familiarity is not always a bad thing, and if the script, by Shauna Cross, piles sports movie and [[coming-of-age]] touchstones into a veritable [[cairn]] of [[cliché]]s, the cast shows enough agility and conviction to make them seem almost fresh."{{cite news| url= https://www.nytimes.com/2009/10/02/movies/02whip.html |title=Misfits With Big Hearts and Roller-Derby Grit |date= October 2, 2009 | first= A. O.| last= Scott| authorlink = A. O. Scott| work= [[The New York Times]] | accessdate= June 30, 2011}} [[Roger Ebert]] said it's a "coming-together of two free spirits, Drew Barrymore and Ellen Page, and while it may not reflect the kind of female empowerment [[Gloria Steinem]] had in mind, it has guts, charm, and a black-and-blue sweetness."{{cite news| date= September 30, 2009 | url= https://www.rogerebert.com/reviews/whip-it-2009 |title=Whip It |first= Roger | last= Ebert| authorlink = Roger Ebert| work = RogerEbert.com | accessdate= June 30, 2011}} According to ''The Miami Herald'', "''Whip It'' is completely predictable from the first frame. It also is ridiculously, utterly entertaining. Drew Barrymore's smashing directorial debut harkens back to an era in which Hollywood studio pictures could still move and enthrall the audience while plying in hoary cliches."{{cite news| date= September 30, 2009 | url= http://miamiherald.typepad.com/reeling/2009/09/review-whip-it.html |title=Review: ''Whip It''|first= Rene | last= Rodriguez| work= [[The Miami Herald]] | accessdate= June 30, 2011}} ===Box office=== ''Whip It'' was not financially successful.{{cite web|last1=Reynolds|first1=Hurt|title=After Box Office Bummer, Whip It Heads Home|url=http://www.derbynewsnetwork.com/2010/01/after_box_office_bummer_emwhip_item_heads_home|publisher=Derby News Network|accessdate=3 July 2014|date=3 January 2010}}{{cite web|last1=Gant|first1=Charles|title=Sunny skies are a downer for UK box office|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2010/apr/13/uk-box-office|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=3 July 2014|date=13 April 2010}} Initial studio estimates showed ''Whip It'' in a tie for #6 in its opening weekend, tying with the widely released ''[[Capitalism: A Love Story]]'', and it wound up taking sixth place with $4,650,812.[http://www.boxofficemojo.com/weekend/chart/?yr=2009&wknd=40&p=.htm WEEKEND BOX OFFICE] The film grossed $13,043,363 in North America. It grossed $3,589,672 in foreign movie sales, for a grand total of $16,633,035 worldwide. Production cost of the film was $15 million.{{cite web |title = Whip It (2009) |url = http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=whipit.htm |work = [[Box Office Mojo]] |accessdate = January 12, 2010 }} ===Accolades=== {| class="wikitable sortable" ! Year ! Award ! Category ! Nominee ! Result |- | rowspan="5"| 2009 | [[Alliance of Women Film Journalists]] | Perseverance Award | Drew Barrymore | {{nom}} |- | [[Stockholm Film Festival]] | [[Bronze Horse Award]] | Drew Barrymore | {{nom}} |- | [[Women Film Critics Circle Awards]] | Best Comedic Actress | [[Ellen Page]] | {{nom}} |- | rowspan="2" | [[Women's Image Network Awards]] | rowspan="2" | Outstanding Actress Feature Film | Ellen Page | {{nom}} |- | Drew Barrymore | {{nom}} |- | 2010 | [[Dorian Awards]] | Campy Film of the Year | ''Whip It!'' | {{nom}} |} ==Soundtrack== {{Infobox album | name = Whip It | type = Soundtrack | artist = various artists | cover = | alt = | released = September 29, 2009 | recorded = 2009 | venue = | studio = | genre = Movie Soundtrack | length = 58:28 | label = [[Rhino Entertainment]] | producer = Various Artists | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = | next_year = }} The film has a 58-song playlist, with a wide range of styles and genres.[http://www.what-song.com/movie/title.php?Title=Whip%20It Whip It] at what-song.com Nineteen tracks appear on the CD of the soundtrack, with additional tracks at various MP3 stores. According to [[Allmusic]], "The disc is a blend of familiar old standbys (including a glittering remix of the Chordettes' "Lollipop") and indie acts (among them Barrymore's ex-boyfriend [[Fabrizio Moretti]]'s band Little Joy), achieving the kind of safely edgy balance that embodies the Fox Searchlight aesthetic (that is, it's quirky enough to appeal to the cool kids, but never strays too far from the mainstream)."{{Allmusic| class=album| id= r1639481|label= Whip It (Original Soundtrack)| accessdate=2011-06-30}} ===Track listing=== # [[Tilly and the Wall]] – "Pot Kettle Black" # [[Ramones]] – "[[Sheena Is a Punk Rocker]]" # [[Cut Chemist]] featuring Hymnal – "What's the Altitude" # [[The Breeders]] – "Bang On" # [[The Raveonettes]] – "Dead Sound" # [[Clap Your Hands Say Yeah]] – "Blue Turning Grey" # [[Jens Lekman]] – "Your Arms Around Me" # [[Gotye]] – "[[Learnalilgivinanlovin]]" # [[Peaches (musician)|Peaches]] – "[[Boys Wanna Be Her]]" # [[Dolly Parton]] – "[[Jolene (song)|Jolene]]" # [[38 Special (band)|38 Special]] – "[[Caught Up in You]]" # [[Har Mar Superstar]] featuring [[Adam Green (musician)|Adam Green]] – "[[Never My Love]]" # [[Goose (band)|Goose]] – "Black Gloves" # [[The Ettes]] – "Crown of Age" # [[Landon Pigg]] featuring Turbo Fruits – "High Times" # [[Little Joy]] – "Unattainable" # [[The Chordettes]] – "[[Lollipop (1958 song)|Lollipop]] ([[Squeak E. {{Refimprove|date=November 2016}} {{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Štadión pod Zoborom | image = [[File:FC_Nitra.jpg|300px]] '''[[UEFA stadium categories|UEFA]]''' [[File:Nuvola apps mozilla.png|12px]][[File:Nuvola apps mozilla.png|12px]][[File:Nuvola apps mozilla.png|12px]] | location = [[Nitra]], [[Slovakia]] | coordinates = {{Coord|48.3218565|18.087506|region:SK-BC_type:landmark_source:kolossus-dewiki|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = | opened = 1909 | renovated = 2018 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[FC Nitra]] | operator = [[FC Nitra]] | construction_cost = renovation 7.9 million [[Euro|€]] in 2016-2018 | architect = | former_names = | tenants = [[FC Nitra]] (1909-present)
[[2013 UEFA European Under-17 Championship|UEFA U-17 Championship]] (2013)
[[ŠKF Sereď]] (2018-present) | seating_capacity = 7,480 | dimensions = }} '''Štadión pod Zoborom''' is a multi-use [[stadium]] in [[Nitra]], [[Slovakia]]. It is used mostly for [[football (soccer)|football]] matches and is the home ground of [[FC Nitra]]. The original capacity was 11.340, current capacity is 7,480.http://www.fortunaliga.sk/clanok/821-vsetko-sa-chysta-na-premieru-proti-dac == Reconstruction== In 2018 began reconstruction of the stadium for 7,480 spectators. The estimated cost is €7.9 million. [[Fico's Second Cabinet|Slovak government]] provided €2.4 million of the cost. City of [[Nitra]] provided €5.5 millionhttps://profutbal.sk/clanok/228251-slzami-pokrsteny-stadion-fc-nitra-pychou-zazrakom-a-prikladom-pre-ostatnych ==International matches== Štadión pod Zoborom has hosted two friendly match of the [[Slovakia national football team]]. {{footballbox_collapsible |date = 27 March 1996 |time =
